speaker: JERRY
words: You know, why we're here? To be out, this is out...and out is one of the single most enjoyable experiences of life. People...did you ever hear people talking about "We should go out"? This is what they're talking about...this whole thing, we're all out now, no one is home. Not one person here is home, we're all out! There are people tryin' to find us, they don't know where we are. (imitates one of these people "tryin' to find us"; pretends his hand is a phone) "Did you ring?, I can't find him." (imitates other person on phone) "Where did he go?" (the first person again) "He didn't tell me where he was going". He must have gone out. You wanna go out: you get ready, you pick out the clothes, right? You take the shower, you get all ready, get the cash, get your friends, the car, the spot, the reservation...There you're staring around, whatta you do? You go: "We gotta be getting back". Once you're out, you wanna get back! You wanna go to sleep, you wanna get up, you wanna go out again tomorrow, right? Where ever you are in life, it's my feeling, you've gotta go.

speaker: JERRY
words: Seems to me, that button is in the worst possible spot. (talking about George's shirt) The second button literally makes or breaks the shirt, look at it: it's too high! It's in no-man's-land, you look like you live with your mother.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Are you through? (kind of irritated)

speaker: JERRY
words: You do of course try on, when you buy?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes, it was purple, I liked it, I don't actually recall considering the buttons.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, you don't recall?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (pretends he's talking into a microphone) Uh, no, not at this time.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, senator, I just like to know, what you knew and when you knew it. (a waitress approaches the table)

speaker: WAITRESS
words: Mister Seinfeld. (she pours coffee in his cup) Mister Costanza. (she wants to pour coffee, but George stops her)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Are, are you sure this is decaf? Where's the orange indicator?

speaker: WAITRESS
words: It's missing, I have to do it in my head: decaf left, regular right, decaf left, regular right...it's very challenging work. (ironically)

speaker: JERRY
words: Can you relax, it's a cup of coffee, Claire is a professional waitress.

speaker: WAITRESS
words: Trust me George: no one has any interest in seeing you on caffeine. (she pours the coffee and walks away)

speaker: GEORGE
words: How come you're not doin' the second show tomorrow?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, there's this uh, woman might be comin' in.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Wait a second, wait a second, what coming in, what woman is coming in?

speaker: JERRY
words: I told you about Laura, the girl I met in Michigan?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, you didn't!

speaker: JERRY
words: I thought I told you about it, yes, she teaches political science? I met her the night I did the show in Lansing...(looks in the milk can) There's no milk in here, what...

speaker: GEORGE
words: Wait wait wait, what is she, (takes the milk can from Jerry and puts it on the table) what is she like?

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, she's really great. I mean, she's got like a real warmth about her and she's really bright and really pretty and uh...the conversation though, I mean, it was...talking with her is like talking with you, but, ya know, obviously much better.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (with a big smile) So, ya know, what, what happened?

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, nothing happened, ya know, but it was great.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, nothing happened, but it was...

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah.

speaker: GEORGE
words: This is great!

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah.

speaker: GEORGE
words: So, ya know, she calls and says she wants to go out with you tomorrow night? God bless! Devil you!

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, well...not exactly. I mean, she said, you know, she called this morning and said she had to come in for a seminar and maybe we'll get together.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (whistles disapproving) Ho ho ho, "Had to"? "Had to come in"?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, but...

speaker: GEORGE
words: "Had to come in" and "maybe we'll get together"? "Had to" and "Maybe"?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah!

speaker: GEORGE
words: No...no...no, I hate to tell you this: you're not gonna see this woman.

speaker: JERRY
words: (indignant) What, are you serious...why, why did she call?

speaker: GEORGE
words: How do I know, maybe, ya know, maybe she wanted to be polite.

speaker: JERRY
words: To be polite? You are insane!

speaker: GEORGE
words: All right, all right, I didn't want to tell you this, you wanna know why she called you?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yes!

speaker: GEORGE
words: You're a back-up, you're a second-line, a just-in-case, a B-plan of contingency!

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, I get it, this is about the button.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (The waitress(Claire) passes the table; George stops her and writes something on his note-block) Claire, Claire, you're a woman, right?

speaker: CLAIRE
words: What gave it away, George?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Uhm...I'd like to ask you...ask you to analyze a hypothetical phone call, ya know, from a female point of view.

speaker: JERRY
words: (to George) Oh, come on now, what are you asking her? Now, how is she gonna know?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (to Claire) Now, a woman calls me, all right? She says she has to (makes some gestures to accent "has to") come to New York on business...

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh you are beautiful! (ironically)

speaker: GEORGE
words: and, and maybe (again some gestures) she'll see me when she gets there, does this woman intend to spend time with me?

speaker: CLAIRE
words: I'd have to say: uuhh, no. (George shows his note-block to Jerry, it says very largely: NO)

speaker: GEORGE
words: (to Claire) So why did she call?

speaker: CLAIRE
words: To be polite.

speaker: GEORGE
words: To be polite, I rest my case.

speaker: JERRY
words: Good. Did you have fun? You have no idea, what you're talking about, now, come on, come with me (stands up), I, I gotta go get my stuff out of the dryer anyway.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'm not gonna watch you do laundry.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, come on, be a "come-with-guy".

speaker: GEORGE
words: Come on, I'm tired.

speaker: CLAIRE
words: (to Jerry) Don't worry, I gave him a little caffeine: he'll perk up.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (takes off his glasses and rubs his eyes; panics) Right, I knew I felt something...! (Jerry is laughing, Claire walks away with a smile)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jerry? I have to tell ya somethin':...this is the dullest moment I've ever experienced. (walks away from the dryer; a man passes George and Jerry)

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, look at this guy! Look, he's got everything, he's got: detergents, sprays, fabric softeners; this is not his first load.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I need a break, Jerry, ya know, I gotta get out of the city, I feel so cramped...

speaker: JERRY
words: And you didn't even hear how she sounded.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What?!

speaker: JERRY
words: Laura.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I can't believe: (falls on his knees) WE ALREADY DISCUSSED THIS!

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, but how could you be so sure?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (gets up) 'Cause it's signals, Jerry (starts snapping his fingers), it's signals! Don't you....all right. Did she even ask you, what you were doin' tomorrow night, if you were busy?

speaker: JERRY
words: No.

speaker: GEORGE
words: She calls you today and she doesn't make a plan for tomorrow? What is that? It's Saturday night!

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What is that? It's ridiculous! (Jerry bobs agreeingly) You don't even know, what hotel she's staying at, you can't call her. That's a signal, Jerry, that's a signal! (snaps his fingers again) Signal!

speaker: JERRY
words: Maybe you're right.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Maybe I'm right? Of course I'm right.

speaker: JERRY
words: This is insane. You know, I don't even know where she's staying! She, she's not gonna call me, this is unbelievable.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (puts an arm around Jerry and whispers) I know, I know. (normal voice) Listen, your stuff has to be done by know, why don't you just see if it's dried?

speaker: JERRY
words: No no no, don't interrupt the cycle. The machine is working, it, it knows what it's doing, just let it finish.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You're gonna "overdry" it.

speaker: JERRY
words: You, you can't "overdry".

speaker: GEORGE
words: Why not?

speaker: JERRY
words: Same as you can't "overwet". (George looks puzzled) You see, once something is wet, it's wet. Same thing with dead: like once you die you're dead, right? Let's say you drop dead and I shoot you: you're not gonna die again, you're already dead. You can't "overdie", you can't "overdry".

speaker: GEORGE
words: (looks at the other persons in the laundry and says to them pointing to Jerry) Any questions?

speaker: JERRY
words: How could she not tell me where she was staying? (George stands by the dryer again and secretly opens it: the dryer stops working and George closes the lid)

speaker: GEORGE
words: (points to the dryer) Look at that: they're done! It's a miracle! (Jerry looks surprised)

speaker: JERRY
words: "Laundry-day" is the only exciting day in the live of clothes. It is...no, think about it: the washing machine is the nightclub of clothes. Ya know, it's dark, there's bubbles happening, they're all kind a dancing around in there...shirt grabs the underwear: "C'mon babe, let's gather". You come by, you open up the lid and they'll: (shows how clothes are acting when you open the lid)...Socks are the most amazing article of clothing. They hate their lives, they're in the shoes with stinky feet, the boring drawers...the dryer is their only chance to escape and they all know it. They knew a escape from the dryer. They plan it in the hamper, the night before: (sock's voice) "Tomorrow, the dryer, I'm goin'...you wait here!" The dryer-door swings open and the sock is waiting up against the side wall. They hope you don't see him and then he goes down the road (shows how the sock is going down the road). They got buttons sewed on their faces: join the puppet show...So they're showing me on television the detergent for getting out blood-stains...Is this a violent image to anybody? Blood-stains? I mean, I, come on, you got a T-shirt with blood-stains all over it, maybe laundry isn't your biggest problem right now...Maybe you oughta get the harpoon out your chest first.

speaker: JERRY
words: (The phone rings. He picks it up and says:) If you know what happened in the Mets-game, don't say anything, I taped it, hello... Yeah, no, I'm sorry, you have the wrong number...Yeah, no (somebody knocks at the door) Yeah? (to the door, while still at the phone)

speaker: KRAMER
words: (enters) Are you up?

speaker: JERRY
words: (To Kramer) Yeah...(in the phone) Yeah, people do move! Have you ever seen the big trucks out on the street? Yeah, no problem (hangs up the phone).

speaker: KRAMER
words: Boy, the Mets blew it tonight, huh?

speaker: JERRY
words: (upset) Ooohhhh, what are you doing? Kramer, it's a tape! (actually I can't understand the name; maybe "Kramer" wasn't named "Kramer" in the pilot!) I taped the game, it's one o'clock in the morning! I avoided human contact all night to watch this.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey, I'm sorry, I...ya know, I, I thought you knew...(takes two loaves of bread out of his pockets) You got any meat?

speaker: JERRY
words: (a little irritated) Meat? I don't, I don't know, go...hunt! (Kramer walks to the refrigerator and sticks his head in) Well what, what happened in the game anyway?

speaker: KRAMER
words: (still with his head in the refrigerator) What happened? Well, they STUNK, that's what happened! (takes some meat from the refrigerator and closes it) Ya know, I almost wound up going to that game.

speaker: JERRY
words: (cynical) Yeah you almost went to the game. You haven't been out of the building in ten years!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah. (Jerry sits down on the couch. Kramer sits down next to him and starts turning over the pages of a magazine. Suddenly he spots an article he likes and tears it out. Jerry looks at him with a "what-the-h...-are-you-doing-look" and Kramer asks:) Are you done with this?

speaker: JERRY
words: No.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (glues the article back with his own saliva and puts the magazine back on the table) When you're done, let me know.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, yeah...you can have it tomorrow.

speaker: KRAMER
words: I thought I wasn't allowed to be in here this weekend.

speaker: JERRY
words: No, it's OK now, that, that girl is not comin' uh, I, I misread the whole thing.

speaker: KRAMER
words: You want me to talk to her?

speaker: JERRY
words: I don't think so.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, I can be very persuasive. Do you know that I was almost... a lawyer. (shows with his fingers how close it was)

speaker: JERRY
words: That close, huh?

speaker: KRAMER
words: You better believe it. (The phone rings. Jerry picks it up)

speaker: JERRY
words: Hello...Oh, hi, Laura.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Give me it...let me talk to her (continues this way).

speaker: JERRY
words: (gestures Kramer to shut up) No believe me, I'm always up at this hour. How are you?...great...sure...What time does the plane get in?...I got my friend George to take me...(Kramer suddenly notices something in the Mets-game on TV)...

speaker: KRAMER
words: A SLIDE!...Wow!

speaker: JERRY
words: ...No, it's, it's just my neighbour...uhm...yeah, I got it (takes a pencil and a cereal box to write on) ten-fifteen...No, don't be silly, go ahead and ask...Yeah, sure...OK, great, no no, it's no trouble at all...I'll see you tomorrow...great, bye. (hangs up the phone; to Kramer:) I, I don't believe it...That, that was her. She wants to stay here!

speaker: JERRY
words: If my father was moving this he'd had to have a cigarette in his mouth the whole way. (talks from now on like he has a cigarette in his mouth) Have you got your end?...Your end's got to come down first, easy now, drop it down...drop it down, your end's got to come down.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Ya know, I can't believe you're bringin' in an extra bed for woman, that wants to sleep with you. Why don't you bring in an extra guy too? (sits down)

speaker: JERRY
words: (hands George a beer) Look, it's a very awkward situation, I, I don't wanna be presumptuous.

speaker: GEORGE
words: All right, all right, one more time, one more time! What was the EXACT phrasing of the request?

speaker: JERRY
words: All right, she said she couldn't find a decent hotel- room...

speaker: GEORGE
words: A decent hotel-room...

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, a decent hotel-room, would it be terribly inconvenient if she stayed at my place.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You can't be serious. This is New York city: there must be eleven million decent hotel-rooms! Whatta ya need? A flag? (waves with his handkerchief) This is the signal, Jerry, this is the signal!

speaker: JERRY
words: (cynical) This is the signal. Thank you, mister Signal, where were you yesterday?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I think I was affected by the caffeine. (suddenly a dog enters the apartment and jumps George at the couch) HO, HO, HO, GOOD DOG (etc.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: (walks in behind the dog and closes the door) He really likes you, George.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (ironically) Well, that's flattering.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (the dog runs to the bathroom and apparently starts drinking from the toilet) Oh, he's getting' a drink of water. (sees the mattress on the floor) Is this for that girl?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Why even give her an option?

speaker: JERRY
words: This is a person I like, it's not: "How to score on spring break".

speaker: GEORGE
words: Right, can we go? 'Cause I'm double-parked, I'm gonna get a ticket.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, OK. Oh, wait a second. Oh, I, I forgot to clean the bathroom.

speaker: GEORGE
words: So what? That's good.

speaker: JERRY
words: Now, how could that be good?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Because filth is good...Whatta you think: rock stars have sponges and ammonia lyin' around the bathroom? They, they have a woman comin' over: "I've gotta tidy up? Yeah right, in these matters you never do what your instincts tell you. Always, ALWAYS do the opposite.

speaker: JERRY
words: This is how you operate?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah, I wish.

speaker: JERRY
words: Let me just wipe the sink.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (stands up from the couch and yells.) WHY EVEN GIVE HER AN OPTION FOR? (Jerry walks to the bathroom and closes the door; to George, while pointing to the mattress) It's unbelievable.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah.

speaker: KRAMER
words: ...How's the real estate-business?

speaker: GEORGE
words: ...(surprised he asked) It's uh, not bad, it's comin' along...Why? Did you need something.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Do you handle any of that commercial...real estate?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, I might be getting in to that.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (slaps George on the arm) You keep me posted!

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'm aware of you, all right, let's go (opens the bathroom door), let's go! (Jerry and the dog come out) You're on stage in 25 minutes.

speaker: JERRY
words: The dating world is not a fun world...it's a pressure world, it's a world of tension, it's a world of pain...and ya know, if a woman comes over to my house, I gotta get that bathroom ready, 'cause she needs things. Women need equipment. I don't know what they need. I know I don't have it, I know that...Ya know what they need, women seem to need a lot of cotton-balls. This is the one I'm, always has been one of the amazing things to me...I have no cotton-balls, we're all human beings, what is the story? I've never had one...I never bought one, I never needed one, I've never been in a situation, when I thought to myself: "I could use a cotton-ball right now"...I can certainly get out of this mess...Women need them and they don't need one or two, they need thousands of them, they need bags, they're like peat-moss bags, have you ever seen these giant bags? They're huge and two days later, they're out, they're gone, the, the bag is empty, where are the cotton-balls, ladies? What are you doin' with them? The only time I ever see'em is in the bottom of your little waste basket, there's two or three, that look like they've been through some horrible experience... tortured, interrogated, I don't know what happened to them...I once went out with a girl who's left a little zip-lock-baggy of cotton-balls over my house. I don't know what to do with them, I took them out, I put them on my kitchen floor like little tumbleweeds. I thought maybe the cockroaches would see it, figure this is a dead town: "Let's move on"... The dating world is a world of pressure. Let's face it: a date is a job-interview, that lasts all night. The only difference between a date and a job-interview is: not many job-interviews is there a chance you'll end up naked at the end of it...ya know: "Well, Bill, the boss thinks you're the man for the position, why don't you strip down and meet some of the people you'll be workin' with?".

speaker: JERRY
words: Wouldn't it be great if you could ask a woman what she's thinking?

speaker: GEORGE
words: What a world that would be, if you just could ask a woman what she's thinkin'.

speaker: JERRY
words: Ya know, instead, I'm like a detective: I've gotta pick up clues, the whole thing is a murder investigation.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Listen, listen, don't get worked up, 'cause you're gonna know the whole story the minute she steps off the plane.

speaker: JERRY
words: Really? How?

speaker: GEORGE
words: 'Cause it's all in the greeting.

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh-huh.

speaker: GEORGE
words: All right, if she puts the bags down before she greets you, that's a good sign.

speaker: JERRY
words: Right.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Ya know, anything in the, in the "lip-area" is good.

speaker: JERRY
words: "Lip-area".

speaker: GEORGE
words: Ya know a hug: definitely good.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hug is definitely good.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Sure.

speaker: JERRY
words: Although what if it's one of those hugs where the shoulders are touching, the hips are eight feet apart?

speaker: GEORGE
words: That's so brutal, I hate that.

speaker: JERRY
words: Ya know how they do that?

speaker: GEORGE
words: That's why, ya know, a shake is bad.

speaker: JERRY
words: Shake is bad, but what if it's the "two-hander"? The hand on the bottom, the hand on the top, the warm look in the eyes?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hand-sandwich.

speaker: JERRY
words: Right.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I see, well, that's open to interpretation. Because so much depends on the layering and the quality of the wetness in the eyes...(suddenly a woman approaches Jerry from behind and puts her hands over Jerry's eyes)

speaker: LAURA
words: Guess who?

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, hey.

speaker: LAURA AND JERRY
words: Heeeey! (they take each others hands like they're planning to do a folk dance; George is looking puzzled)

speaker: JERRY
words: It's good to see you.

speaker: LAURA
words: Hi.

speaker: JERRY
words: This is my friend George.

speaker: LAURA
words: (shakes George's hand) Hi, how nice to meet you.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hi, how are you?

speaker: JERRY
words: This is Laura.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Laura, sure.

speaker: JERRY
words: (to Laura) I can't believe you're here.

speaker: GEORGE AND JERRY
words: Ooh yeah, the bags, sure. (they pick up the bags)

speaker: LAURA
words: Oh, thank you.

speaker: JERRY
words: (privately to George) Now that was an interesting greeting, did you notice that, George?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes, the "surprise-blindfold-greeting". That wasn't in the manual, I don't know.

speaker: JERRY
words: So uh, what do ya think?

speaker: LAURA
words: Ooohhh, wow! This place isn't so bad.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, it kind a motivates me to work on the road...So uh, make yourself at home. (Laura sits down on the couch, takes off her shoes and opens some buttons of her shirt) So uh, can I get you anything? Uuhhh, bread, water...salad-dressing?

speaker: LAURA
words: (laughs) Actually uhm, do you have any wine?

speaker: LAURA
words: Oh, do, do you mind if I turn this down? (points to the lamp)

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh, no, yeah, go right ahead. (she turns down the lamp)

speaker: LAURA
words: Uh, Jerry, uh, I was wondering: would it be possible, and if it's not, fine, for me to stay here tomorrow night too?

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh, yeah, yeah, sure, why don't you stay? Yeah, uhm...What is your, what is your schedule for tomorrow? Are you, are you doin' anything?

speaker: LAURA
words: No, I'd love to do something, uh, I have my seminar in the morning, then after that I'm right open.

speaker: JERRY
words: Really? What would you like to do?

speaker: LAURA
words: Well...now I know this sounds touristy, but I'd just love to go on one of those five-hour-boat-rides around Manhattan.

speaker: JERRY
words: (doubtfully) Yeah, we could do that...why not, why not. (pours the wine) I'm just, I'm really glad you're here. (the phone rings; he picks it up) Yeah, hello...yes...yes, she is, hold on. (to Laura) Uhm, it's for you.

speaker: LAURA
words: (she takes the phone) Hello?...Hi!...no no it was great, right on time...no, I, I'm gonna stay here tomorrow...yes, yes it's fine..no, we're goin' on a boat-ride...don't be silly...I'm not gonna have this conversation...look I, I'll call you tomorrow...OK, bye (she hangs up the phone). Never get engaged.

speaker: JERRY
words: You're engaged?

speaker: LAURA
words: You, you really have no idea what it's like until you actually do it and I'm on this emotional roller coaster.

speaker: JERRY
words: You're engaged? (still can't believe it)

speaker: LAURA
words: Ya know, I can't believe it myself sometimes. You have to start thinking in terms of "we", uh, it's a very stressful situation.

speaker: JERRY
words: You're engaged! (like he's answering his own question)

speaker: LAURA
words: Yeah...yeah, he's a great guy...

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah.

speaker: LAURA
words: You'd really like him...ya know, I can't wait to get on that boat.

speaker: JERRY
words: Me too!

speaker: JERRY
words: I swear, I have absolutely no idea what women are thinking. I don't get it, OK? I, I, I admit, I, I'm not getting the signals. I am not getting it! Women, they're so subtle, their little...everything they do is subtle...men are not subtle, we are obvious. Women know what men want, men know what men want, what do we want? We want women, that's it!...It's the only thing we know for sure, it really is: we want women. How do we get them? Oh, we don't know 'bout that, we don't know. The next step after that we have no idea. This is why you see men honking car-horns, yelling from construction sites. These are the best ideas we've had so far...The car-horn-honk, is that a beauty? Have you seen men doing this? What is this? The man is in the car, the woman walks by the front of the car, he honks: (imitates horn).

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: So, I'm on line at the supermarket. Two women in front of me. One of

speaker: AUDIENCE
words: Cheque

speaker: JERRY
words: Cheque. Now, the fact is, if it's a woman in front of you that's

speaker: JERRY
words: What's that one?

speaker: ELAINE
words: "Coccoon II: The Return". I guess they didn't like it up there...

speaker: JERRY

words: Manny..

speaker: JERRY
words: I don't know. What do you do when a neighbor is making, like, a lot of noise at three o' clock in the morning? I mean, can you knock on someone's door and tell them to keep it down? You're really altering your whole self-image, I mean, what am I? Fred Mertz now? What's happening to me? Can I do this? Am I a shusher? I used to be a shushee. There's a lot of shushing going on in movie theaters. People are always shushing. Shh..shh.... shhh... shhh.. Doesn't work, 'cause nobody knows where a shush is coming from. They just hear a Shh. "Was that a shush? I think somebody just shushed me." Some people you can't shush in a movie theater. There's always that certain group of people, isn't it. They're talking and talking, and everyone around them is shushing them, and shushing them. They won't shush. They're the unshushables.

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: I have to tell you that I did some very exciting news recently, and I don't know if I should really tell you exactly what it is because it's really not a definite thing yet. Well, I will tell you what I know so far. According to the information that I have in the envelope that I've received, it seems that I may have already won some very valuable prizes. Well, thank you, thank you very much, well thank you. It's very nice to hear that. But, in all honesty, I have to say, I didn't even know I was in this thing. But, according to the readout, it looks like I am among the top people that they are considering. You know, that's what annoys me about the sweepstakes companies, they always tease you with that, "You may have already won." I'd like once for a sweepstakes company to have some guts, come out with the truth, just tell people the truth one time. Send out envelopes, "You have definitely lost!" You turn it over, giant printing, "Not even close!" You open it up, there's this whole letter of explanation, "Even we cannot believe how badly you've done in this contest."

speaker: JERRY
words: (Trying to get the box through the door. To Kramer) To the right. (They get it through)

words: That took awhile.

words: (Sarcastic) Don't get up.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'd like to help, but my neck..

speaker: JERRY
words: Since my grandfather died. I was suppose to send it down to my parents in Florida, but they didn't want it. They told me to get rid of it, but I felt funny and then I sort of forgot about it. And it's been sitting down there for three years.. until he saw it. (To Kramer) Alright, so, just take what you want and let's get it out of here.

words: What's in it?

words: (Pulls out some socks) You want these? Knee socks. You don't wear knee socks.

words: No, go ahead. (Looks around his apartment) Look at this place. I can't wait to get it cleaned.

words: I know someone who'll do it. She's good. She's honest.

words: Students can't clean. It's anathema. (Jerry's confused) ..They don't like it.

words: How long have you been waiting to squeeze that into a conversation?

words: Now this, I like.

words: Wait a second. I can't believe this! Let me see this.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Getting possesive) Wait, wait, wait..

words: Let me just see it.

words: Come on..

words: Let me just see it for a second. Oh my God, it's exactly the same!

speaker: JERRY
words: What?

speaker: GEORGE
words: When I was ten years old, my parents had this very same statue on the mantle of our apartment. Exactly. And, one day, I grabbed it, and I was using it as a microphone. I was singing, "MacArthur Park", and I got to the part about, "I'll never have that recipe again," and it slipped out of my hand and it broke. My parents looked at me like I smashed the ten commandments. To this day, they bring it up. It was the single most damaging experience in my life, aside from seeing my father naked.

speaker: KRAMER
words: C'mon, George. I saw it first.

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, Kramer. I have to have this statue.

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, I got dibs!

speaker: GEORGE
words: What? No dibs! I need this statue. C'mon, give it!

words: Yeah, good, good.

words: What?! Wait a minute. No, no, no. What are you doing? No, no, oh, oh, okay. He's out. I get it.

words: I don't really feel that comfortable with a maid, either, because there's that guilt when you have someone cleaning your house. You know, you're sitting there on your sofa, and they go by with the vacuum, "I'm really sorry about this. I don't know why I let that stuff over there." And that's why I could never be a maid, because I'd have an attitude. I'd find them, whereever they are in the house, "Oh, I suppose you couldn't do this? No, don't get up, let me clean up your filth. No, you couldn't dust. No, this is too tough, isn't it?"

words: He really did an amazing job, look! He uncoagulated the top of the dishwashing liquid. (Opens refrigerator) He cleaned out the bottom of the little egg cups. Come here, look at this. (Gets on his knees) He cleaned the little one-inch area between the refrigerator and the counter. How did he get in there? He must be like Rubber Man!

words: I can't believe it! This guy ripped me off!

words: Do you realize what you're saying?

words: Lemon?

words: (Causual) Uh.. sure, yeah..

words: Are you sure?

words: The pastries!

words: Maybe it just looks the same. Maybe it's just a coincidence.

words: I never saw the statue.

words: I had a statue! What should I do?

words: I don't know.

speaker: JERRY
words: ..I'll call Kramer. He can check my house. (Grabs the phone, and dials)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh Jerry, don't blow this for me.

speaker: JERRY
words: Don't worry.. (Whispering into the phone) Kramer! Kramer!.. It's Jerry!.. Jerry! .. from next door!.. Never mind where I am!.. Yes, Jerry Seinfeld!.. (Rava enters with a manuscript. Jerry starts talking casually)

speaker: JERRY
words: Ma, I told ya, just dip the bread in the batter, and put in right in the pan. Okay, bye. (Hangs up) My mother.. She forgot how to make French Toast. You know how mothers are.

words: My mother left us when I was six years old. All seven of us. He ever heard from her again. I hope she's rotting in an alley somewhere.

words: My mom's down in Florida.. she's go one of those condos.. Hot down there in the summer. You ever been down there?

words: I love these pastries. You know, in Scandinavian mythology, the pastries were the food of the gods.

words: ..Listen, I just remembered.. I'm ..uh, getting a facial.

words: (Takes the manuscript) Oh, see you tomarrow morning.

words: Oh, how about dinner?

words: No, I don't eat dinner. Dinner's for suckers. (They leave)

words: (On the phone) Uh huh.. yeah.. Okay, thanks anyway. Bye. (Hangs up) Nope, the cop says it's my word against his. There's nothing they can do.

words: Let's go get him.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, right.

words: We can't just let him get away with this.

words: Do you realize how crazy he had to be to do something like this? He knew I was gonna know it's missing, and he took it! And of all things to take - I left my watch, tape recorder, stereo. He's crazy.

words: You wanta go get him?

words: Well, then, if he's crazy you should just forget it.

words: Who is this Rava?

words: I say we get him.

words: No!

words: Let me just call him.

speaker: JERRY
words: I'll call him. (Picks up the cordless phone. Kramer, George, and Elaine all struggle for control of the other - so they can listen in on the conversation. As Jerry's talking, the three others still fight) Hello, Ray? ..Hi, Ray, this is Rava's friend, Elaine's frined, Jerry.. The King of Comedy.. right. Listen, you know that statue on your mantle, the one with the blue lady? (To Kramer and George) Will you shut up?! (To Ray) Yeah, you don't want to talk about it over the phone? You don't want Rava to hear? ..Yeah, I understand.. You know that coffee shop near my house, Monk's? ..Alright, tomarrow. One o' clock. Great, okay, bye. (Hangs up)

words: (Scrambling) Alright, look, look, look, Let's say he stole it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, he stole it?

speaker: ELAINE
words: C'mon, you can't do anything about it. The cops won't do anything. What, are you going to fight him? Why don't you just.. forget it?

words: No.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (To Jerry, without looking at him) I thought you said one o' clock.

speaker: JERRY
words: Relax, he's late. He's always late. It's part of his "M.O."

speaker: GEORGE
words: Remember, don't take any crap.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, yeah.. don't worry about it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'll be right here.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Sarcastic) That's comforting.. Shh. He's here. (Greeting him) Ray?

speaker: RAY
words: (Stands next to the table) Oh, Jerry. I can't believe you asked me about that statue. Do you know how much trouble you could've got me into?

speaker: JERRY
words: ..Well, I didn't..

words: Rava was standing right next to me. I never told her where I got the statue.

words: (Muttering to himself) I wonder why.

words: Well, just give it back, and I won't say anything.

words: Give it back?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah.

speaker: RAY
words: What are you talking about?

speaker: JERRY
words: What are you talking about?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Muttering) What is he talking about..

speaker: RAY
words: I'm talking about the statue.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, me too.

words: Give it back to whom?

words: Me.

words: (To himself) Yeah, him.

words: You?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah. Me.

speaker: RAY
words: I'm not getting this.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (To himself) You already got it.

speaker: RAY
words: What are you saying?

speaker: JERRY
words: What am I saying?

words: (To himself) Take a wild guess.

words: Are you saying I stole your statue?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (To himself) What a mind.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, I..

speaker: RAY
words: I can't believe what I'm hearing.

speaker: JERRY
words: I can't believe what I'm hearing.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (to himself) I can't believe what I'm hearing.

words: (To Himself) A pawn shop?

words: A pawn shop?

words: Yes. In Chinatown with the money I earned cleaning people's apartments.

words: (To himself) And cleaning them out.

words: Oh, excuse me.. Look, Ray, you were the only person in my house.

speaker: RAY
words: What's behind this? It's Rava, isn't it?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (To himself) Again with the Rava.

speaker: RAY
words: You want her.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Joking) No, she's a little too cheery for me.

speaker: RAY
words: (Losing it) She's from Finland, for crying out loud. Finland! Do you understand?!

speaker: JERRY
words: I know Finland. They're neutral.

speaker: RAY
words: Is it me? Do I rub you the wrong way?

speaker: JERRY
words: No, I actually find you quite charming.. a bit verbose at times.

words: (Mocking) "Oh, I find you so charming" ..You wuss.

words: (To George) Did you call me a wuss?

speaker: RAY
words: What did you say?

words: I said luss.. I'm at a luss..

words: I would just love to take you down to the shop where I got it.

words: That's not necessary. (George slams his menu down on the table in anger) You know, maybe it's not that bad an idea.

speaker: RAY
words: And I would love to. Nothing would please me more. But, unfortunately, the guy retired and moved to Singapore.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Muttering to himself) Singapore?! Do you hear this?

words: If you really want, maybe I can contact the guy in Singapore aand have him make a photostat of the receipt and send it over.

My parents live in Florida, and if you go down there and you forget your bathing suits then they want you to wear one of theirs. You know how that gets? "You need trunks son? I've got trunks for you. You can wear my trunks." Fathers don't wear bathing suits, they wear trunks. It's kind of the same thing a tree would wear if it went swimming. So I get in the water with in thing and it's like floating around me somewhere. Did you ever put on a bathing suit that you don't even know exactly where you are inside the bathing suit? words: Because you see, George, having the keys to Jerry's apartment? That kept me in a fantasy world. Every time I went over to his house, it was like I was on vacation. words: I don't even want to talk about it anymore. What were you thinking? What was going on in your mind? Artistic integrity? Where, where did you come up with that? You're not artistic and you have no integrity. You know you really need some help. A regular psychiatrist couldn't even help you. You need to go to like Vienna or something. You know what I mean? You need to get involved at the University level. Like where Freud studied and have all those people looking at you and checking up on you. That's the kind of help you need. Not the once a week for eighty bucks. No. You need a team. A team of psychiatrists working round the clock thinking about you, having conferences, observing you, like the way they did with the Elephant Man. That's what I'm talking about because that's the only way you're going to get better.

words: Well, that whole storyline about a guy who gets into a car accident, doesn't have any insurance, so the judge sentences him to be a butler? I didn't really buy that.

words: Let me tell you who did, uh, buy it...we pitched this story to Russell Dalrymple, the president of NBC, and he ate it up with a spoon.

words: George, if you're going to be in a creative field, you're going to have to learn how to deal with criticism.

words: I think you'd better go.

words: I guess she didn't think it was funny.

words: Oh, she didn't think it was funny. What is she, Rowan & Martin? We're supposed to meet with NBC tomorrow! She completely shattered my confidence. And I'm paying for this, she's my employee!

words: I thought your mother's paying for it.

words: And she slaves to earn every penny. So that someday, I might be able to walk up to a woman and say, "Yes, I'm bald, but I'm still a good person."

words: What did I think of it? (Manufactures a cough instead of answering. Kramer enters.)

words: Hey, buddy, I got something to tell ya. (Elaine runs towards to the bathroom in lieu of answering Jerry's question.)

words: Hey, one second, you don't get off that easy. C'mon, tell me what you thought.

words: Well, you know, I...

words: You what?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, I kissed her.

speaker: JERRY
words: You kissed her?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Right on the mouth.

speaker: JERRY
words: What kinda great friend are you? How do you go from snubbing to kissing?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, I saw her outside the Y, you know, she came up to me, she started yelling because I snubbed her, and then we started talking a little bit, and I walked her to her building. And just before I left, I put my arm around her waist, I pulled her to me, and I - mmm - I planted one! (Laughs.)

speaker: JERRY
words: And what did she do?

speaker: KRAMER
words: She kissed me back.

speaker: JERRY
words: I don't get this. I go out with this girl three times, she doesn't want to shake my hand - why's she kissing you?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Because I snubbed her. You see? Women, they like that! Yes! I understand women. The snub is good, they love the snub!

speaker: GEORGE
words: No they don't. I tried that once. I snubbed for a year. Nothing. Every woman I saw, I snubbed. You never saw people so pleased. (Elaine returns from the bathroom.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Ooh, so...I understand you're buying new shoes now at Botticelli's.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What? Who told you that?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Gail Cunningham.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I don't understand, why is this woman talking about my shoes? Why are my shoes a topic of conversation?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, you know, we were just talking, and she mentioned how you're buying your shoes now at Botticelli's.

speaker: ELAINE
words: "How I'm buying my shoes now at Botticelli's!" Did you hear this? (Shoves Jerry and Kramer.)

speaker: JERRY
words: So what?

speaker: ELAINE
words: So what?! She is talking about my shoes! She is discussing my shoes! It is nobody's business where I buy my shoes! (Storms over to the couch and angrily sits down. Jerry, Kramer and George look at Elaine from the kitchen, comically puzzled by her outburst...)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hey! Gail!

speaker: GAIL
words: Elaine...!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Why are you talking about my shoes?

speaker: GAIL
words: What?

speaker: ELAINE
words: My Botticelli shoes. You've been talking about my Botticelli shoes.

speaker: GAIL
words: What are you talking about?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Did you or did you not tell Kramer that I got my shoes at Botticelli's? (A waiter comes over and puts a plate of food on Gail's cutting board.)

speaker: WAITER
words: Too spicy. He wants another one. You got that pasta primavera?

speaker: GAIL
words: Look Elaine, I am very busy here.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Who else have you mentioned my shoes to, huh? I wanna know why my footwear is your conversation!

speaker: GAIL
words: I am not discussing this. This is insane.

speaker: WAITER
words: You got that pasta primavera? Let's go! (Gail passes the plate to the waiter in front of Elaine. Elaine sneezes on it. The waiter brings the pasta to the dining room and serves it to Russell Dalrymple, the president of NBC.) Here you are, Mr. Dalrymple.

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Thank you.

speaker: WAITER
words: Sorry for the delay. Enjoy your lunch.

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Well, come in. (They shake hands.) Awfully sorry to make you come up here, but I really wasn't feeling well enough to go back to the office, and well, it's the only chance I have to meet with you this week.

speaker: JERRY
words: Are you alright?

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Well, it's my stomach. I think there must have been something in the pasta primavera I had for lunch.

speaker: JERRY
words: Where did you eat?

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Pfeiffer's.

speaker: JERRY
words: Ah. I know the chef there.

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Yeah. The food's usually terrific.

speaker: GEORGE
words: My cousin worked for Bouchard's. They used to use the bouilla-base for a toilet. (Jerry and Russell are shocked.)

speaker: RUSSELL
words: What are you saying?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, you didn't hear it from me, but needless to say, if you go in there - stick with the consumee.

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Well, we'd better get started, my daughter's going to be here soon.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, you have a daughter?

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Yeah, she just turned fifteen last week.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Aw, that's a fun age. (Jerry looks at George distastefully.)

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Alright. The script. Now, I've read this thing three times...and everytime I read it...(looks nauseous, struggles not to vomit.)

speaker: JERRY
words: What?

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Excuse me for a second. (Gets up and runs to the bathroom.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Would you like a Pepto-Bismol? I keep them in my wallet...! (Russell goes into the bathroom and shuts the door.) (To Jerry) Do you think he liked it? (From the bathroom, we hear Russell violently heaving his guts.)

speaker: JERRY
words: I'm not sure. (The sounds of Russell vomiting emanate from the bathroom. Jerry and George sit there uncomfortably.) What was that dish he said he had...?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Pasta primavera.

speaker: JERRY
words: Ah. You know, 'primavera' is Italian for 'spring.'

speaker: GEORGE
words: No!

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah.

speaker: RUSSELL

speaker: JERRY
words: No.

words: I really appreciate you coming.

words: Oh, that's O.K. I don't have much time though. So...

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Yes I know. I just-- I can't get you out of my mind. Ever since that-- that day in the restaurant when we met... (we see a flashback from 'The Shoes' of Elaine showing her cleavage and asking Russell for his Ketchup secret)

speaker: RUSSELL
words: But I want you.

words: Is it something I said... or did?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Um... Look Russell... You're a very sweet guy. But I got to be honest with you. I don't like television... and that's your world. That's your life. I mean maybe if you were in... I don't know... Greenpeace or something, that would be different, but network television... I mean, come on, Russell, you're part of the problem.

speaker: RUSSELL
words: Oh Elaine, we're doing some really very interesting things right now. We've got some very exciting pilots for next season. We have one with a bright young comedian, Jerry Seinfeld.

speaker: RUSSELL

speaker: RUSSELL
words: (a little more enthusiast) Well, really, it's very unusual. It's about nothing.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (surprised) What do you mean it's about nothing?

speaker: RUSSELL
words: (starts doing George at the first meeting with NBC in 'The Pitch') For example, what did you do today?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Um, I got up. Um, I went to work. Then I came here.

speaker: RUSSELL
words: There's a show. that's a show.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Russell, see, I'm really not interested in this stuff and I do have to go to work (she gets up). So...

speaker: RUSSELL
words: (stops doing George, he's down again) Elaine, When--when--when are we gonna see each other again.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I'm sorry Russell. I'm sorry O.K.? Bye-bye. (Russell, still sitting watches her leaving).

speaker: JERRY

(hangs up)(to George) Casting tomorrow at NBC. 4:00. We're in business baby, the pilot's on. You're gonna successful. (George looks disappointed)

words: You see, It's right here. It's all white...

words: He said he didn't know what it was.

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright. So?

words: When I asked him if it was cancer, he didn't give me a "get outta here". That's what I wanted to hear: "Cancer? Get outta here?"

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, maybe he doesn't have a "get outta here" kind of personality.

words: How could you be a doctor and not say "get outta here"? It should be part of the training at medical school: "Cancer? Get outta here!" "Go home! What are you crazy? It's a little test. It's nothing. You're a real nut. You know that?" (Jerry gives him half of his sandwich to hopefully shut him up) I told you that God would never let me be successful. I never should've written that pilot. Now the show will be a big hit, we'll make millions of dollars, and I'll be dead. Dead Jerry. Because of this. (showing his lip)

words: Can't you at least die with a little dignity?

words: No I can't. I can't die with dignity. I have no dignity. I want to be the one person who doesn't die with dignity. I live my whole life in shame. Why should I die with dignity?

words: Yeah?

words: Anyway there's at least four of them, and they're all huge. And one is bigger than the next. It's like a Russ Meyer movie.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, all right. Go ahead. (not very interested)

speaker: ELAINE
words: There's this blind guy at a party I was at, and he felt my face for a really long time. You know, to see what I looked like. He almost put his finger up my nose.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hum... ok, what else you got?

speaker: ELAINE
words: OK, I'm not gonna tell you the rest of the list.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, because I didn't think the blind guy did it?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Because you have an attitude.

speaker: JERRY AND ELAINE
words: Oh!

speaker: JERRY
words: Georgio! Nice duds!

speaker: GEORGE
words: You're telling me. (he walks around and the suit makes a swooshing sound) So, what do you think?

speaker: JERRY
words: Did you hear something?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, like a swoosh.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah.

speaker: ELAINE
words: It must be the fabric. It's rubbing between you thighs when you walk. That's what's making that swooshy sound.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I probably didn't hear it on the way over because of the street noise. (he panics) This is no good! I got to meet these guys from MacKenzie for lunch in half an hour!

speaker: JERRY
words: So what? What would they care?

speaker: GEORGE
words: This MacKenzie, he's a bit of a nut. Someone told me he fired the last guy because his nose whistled when he breathed.

speaker: JERRY
words: So you think you're not gonna get the job because your pants make a noise?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Let's say it comes down to me and one other guy. He's got a nice quiet suit, and I'm whooshing all over the place! Who do you think he's gonna hire?

speaker: JERRY
words: You know, I think all these interviews are making you nuts.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey Jerry, I saw your girlfriend was in here before.

speaker: JERRY
words: Audrey?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yep. Sat down, had herself a piece of pie.

speaker: JERRY
words: Was it apple?

speaker: KRAMER
words: What else?

speaker: JERRY
words: This woman is bending my mind into a pretzel!

speaker: STRANGER
words: Do I know you?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hmm... No you don't.

speaker: STRANGER
words: Yeah! You were wearing a G-string and one of those bras with points.

speaker: ELAINE
words: The mannequin!

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, I got to see this thing.

speaker: JERRY
words: Boy, the resemblance is uncanny.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You think you can pose me however you want? That's my ass in your window!

speaker: SALESWOMAN
words: It's our store and our mannequin, we can do whatever we want with it.

speaker: ELAINE
words: No! You take down that mannequin right now, or I'm pressing charges. (Jerry goes along) Yes, this is my attorney.

speaker: SALESWOMAN
words: (to Jerry) Yeah? What law am I breaking?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, I believe there's some legal precedent - Winchell vs. Mahoney,

speaker: ELAINE
words: Uh-huh

speaker: JERRY
words: The Charlie Macarthy hearings.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Uh-huh. Are you taking this down?

speaker: SALESWOMAN
words: I'm getting the manager. (she leaves)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Jerry get the car. (she's getting the mannequin)

speaker: JERRY
words: What are you doing?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Just get the car!

speaker: JERRY
words: Elaine, as your legal counsel I must advise against this.

speaker: JERRY
words: I don't know about you, but I'm getting a hankering for some doublemint gum. I'm dropping you off at work, right?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Where are you going?

speaker: JERRY
words: Poppie's

speaker: MACKENZIE
words: Thanks for meeting me down here George. My office is out of control, (George's pants are making noise) phones ringing, people running in and out. (MacKenzie stops talking and walking, George too) Did you hear something?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, I didn't hear anything.

speaker: MACKENZIE
words: Huh, that's strange. (they start walking again) It's quieter here. We can concentrate without people wooshing around... (he stops again, George too) That sound again. Sure you didn't hear anything?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, can't say as I did.

speaker: MACKENZIE
words: Kind of like a... rustling.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Could be the leaves...

speaker: AUDREY
words: That's right. Poppie's on 77th. Ok we'll see you at 8:00. Bye-bye.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hello.

speaker: AUDREY
words: What are you doing here?

speaker: JERRY
words: So how was the pie?

speaker: AUDREY
words: What pie?

speaker: JERRY
words: The apple pie you had today at Monks

speaker: AUDREY
words: I'm very busy here.

speaker: JERRY
words: Pretty good, wasn'it? I told you you should've tasted it.

words: You better not let Poppie see you here.

words: All right, I'm looking for someone named Poppie.

speaker: AUDREY
words: Uh, who are you?

speaker: HEALTH INSPECTOR
words: Board of health, we've had several complaints.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, about the... uh (Jerry pretend to wash his hands)

speaker: HEALTH INSPECTOR
words: Are you Poppie?

speaker: POPPIE
words: I'm Poppie.

speaker: HEALTH INSPECTOR
words: I think you'd better come with me.

speaker: POPPIE
words: What's the problem?

speaker: AUDREY
words: What do they want from Poppie?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, Poppie's a little sloppy.

speaker: MACKENZIE
words: You taught I'd care about your pants wooshing?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I heard the last guy got fired because his nose whislted.

speaker: MACKENZIE
words: No, no, no. He got fired because he wasn't a team player. That's something we don't joke about at MacKenzie. You'll find we're team here George. We don't tolerate dissent. If you want to go your own way, you're in the wrong place.

speaker: GEORGE
words: No problem there. Conformity is an obsession with me.

speaker: WAITER
words: Chocolate cream pie. Compliments of the house.

speaker: MACKENZIE
words: Oh! Hope you saved room for dessert.

speaker: WAITER
words: (to George) The chef said that he made it special for you.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh... (George looks around and sees the chef hiding behind a plant: it's Bob!)

speaker: MACKENZIE
words: Mmm.. Best pie I've ever tasted. Take a bite George. (George shakes his head doing "no") Well, take a bite. It's delicious. (still shaking) I insist. (still shaking)

speaker: BUSINESSMAN
words: If you're one of us, you'll take a bite.

speaker: JERRY
words: So you didn't get the job.

speaker: GEORGE
words: No. But I was the only one at the table that didn't get violently ill.

speaker: JERRY
words: Kramer, you can't keep avoiding her like this, you're gonna have to say something.

speaker: KRAMER
words: What am I supposed to say?

speaker: JERRY
words: Tell her you lost your itch.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What happened to your itch?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I lost it two days ago. I've been faking it so I wouldn't hurt her feelings.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well you should tell her.

speaker: KRAMER
words: I'll let her down easy. All right. (he gets up and walks to Olive) Well, hi Olive. (she reaches for Kramer's back) No, no. No more of that. There's something I have to tell you.

speaker: OLIVE
words: What?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Uh, well, there's someone else.

speaker: OLIVE
words: Someone else?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, yeah, yeah...

speaker: OLIVE
words: Who is she?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Her. (he points to the Elaine mannequin in Jerry's car)

speaker: OLIVE
words: her?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, there she is. That's my gal.

speaker: OLIVE
words: You're a liar. I've seen her in here before. She's not your girlfriend.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Now Olive, look, I'm sorry.

speaker: OLIVE
words: Why is she wearing her underwear?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, it's a style. (turns back to Jerry) Jerry give me the keys. (Jerry throws his keys to Kramer) Well, I guess we're gonna go for a drive now. She really loves that.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Did you ever solve the riddle of the pie?

speaker: JERRY
words: No. That's one for the ages. But I think they're gonna put Poppie away for a long long time.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You guys are not gonna believe this. I just got a letter from a friend of mine in Chicago who's shopping, and she said she saw a mannequin that looked just like me. What if there're more. Where are they coming from?

speaker: RICKY
words: TR-6? I prefer to think of her as... Elaine.

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: The bus is the single stupidest, fattest, slowest, most despised vehicle on the road. Isn't it? You ever notice when you get behind the bus, people in your car go 'what are you doing? get away, come on.' The back of the bus is like an eclipse isn't it? people are just like 'the sun, where's the sun?' It's like this huge metal ass taking up the whole wind shield of your car. When it pulls out it even sounds like a fat uncle trying to get out of a sofa. (acts like he is trying to get out of a car and makes the sound of a busguy starting to get going)

speaker: GEORGE
words: It's just not good, it's not good.

speaker: JERRY
words: It's not good.

words: Ya

words: Great girl.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Ya

speaker: JERRY
words: Ya, see ya.

words: Deeply in love. If you can't say anything bad about a relationship, you shouldn't say anything at all.

words: (points to George) Ya.

words: Could use a good laugh. You know what kind of pressure that is? Come on, come with me.

words: Na no, I'm not good in these situations. I can't hide my pity. I..I make em feel worse.

words: Oh, stop it.

words: (to Jerry then both Jerry and George) But I got a big problem. The kid I stand in for, he's growing. He was four feet last month, now he's like four-two and a half. He shot up two and a half inches. I can do four-two, four-three is a stretch, any higher than that and I'm gonna be out on my ass doing that paralegal crap.

words: Oh don't worry, you'll crack. Cracking's inevitable, first you crack then you chuckle. That was the motto with the Russians at the Caesar Leningrad... first you crack then you chuckle. (Fulton looks at him not amused) You know because Leningrad when the Nazis attacked, it wasn't a very happy time... because of the war, famine, plus it was cold, very cold... they were eating each other. (Nervous under the pressure; Fulton not finding anything Jerry is saying funny) Maybe this isn't a good time for a visit.

words: Oh, all right ah well... There's a priest, a minister and a rabbi, and they're all staring at him....
