words: What's wrong with him?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I don't know! I'm gonna go and visit him later. (angrily) It would be nice if you got him something. (Punches the the table to accentuate this, and leaves.)

speaker: JERRY
words: We should get him something.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah. You're right.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Do you know that I have been using the same bottle of shampoo for a year? And I shampoo every day. (Carl smiles.) So, what do you think of my conversation?

speaker: CARL
words: Not much! (They both laugh.) I, uh, would have invited you up, but I don't have any furniture.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You don't have any furniture?

speaker: CARL
words: No, I hate furniture. I can't look at it. (They laugh again.)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I can understand that. Pretty good date, huh?

speaker: CARL
words: Yeah! No heavy lifting. (Elaine and Carl look into each others eyes, then kiss.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Anyway, Jerry and Elaine felt very badly about what happened to you, and they wanted you to have this.

speaker: POPPIE
words: What's this? A bottle of wine and a five-alarm chili? They're trying to kill Poppie?!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Why, what...?

speaker: POPPIE
words: Don't they know I have a gastro-intestinal disorder? If I would have any of this, I would die. Then Poppie's no good to anyone! This is a sick, sick joke on Poppie. How could you be friends with those two?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, we're not very close.

speaker: POPPIE
words: They owe me for those ducks. They were flown in from Newfoundland.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, they got good ducks there, huh?

speaker: POPPIE
words: Oh, very good ducks.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I'm in looove!

speaker: JERRY
words: Whoa!

speaker: ELAINE
words: This is it, Jerry! This is it! He is such an incredible person! He's real, he's honest, he's unpretentious...oh, I'm really lucky!

speaker: JERRY
words: Did you tell him I was sorry I didn't offer him the drink?

speaker: ELAINE
words: No, I forgot. And, the best part is, he doesn't play games. You know? There are no games! (Sits down on the couch.)

speaker: JERRY
words: No games? What is the point of dating without games? How do you know if you're winning or losing?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, all I know is, he doesn't like games and he doesn't play games, you know? He has too much character and integrity.

speaker: JERRY
words: Ah ha. And what is his stand on abortion?

speaker: ELAINE
words: What?

speaker: JERRY
words: What is his stand...on abortion?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I'm sure he's pro-choice.

speaker: JERRY
words: How do you know?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Because he, well...he's just so good-looking.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, you should probably ask, because if he's gonna be coming over with those Paccino's pizzas...could be trouble.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'd like to rent Breakfast At Tiffany's.

speaker: CLERK
words: Uh, this is out. Someone has it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Out? Oh no, I've been to four other places, you're the only ones that have had it.

speaker: CLERK
words: Well, I could put it on reserve for you, if you'd like.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Maybe we could call them and ask them to return it.

speaker: CLERK
words: Oh, sorry. We can't do that.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, maybe they're done with it. I could go pick it up.

speaker: CLERK
words: I don't think so. It doesn't work that way.

speaker: VOICE ON INTERCOM
words: Yes?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Uh, excuse me, are you Joe Temple?

speaker: INTERCOM
words: Yes.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Uh, yes, uh...you don't know me, my name is George Costanza...did you happen to rent Breakfast At Tiffany's?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, what's happenin.'

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, you know, Poppie's over at my place. Tonight's the big night. I'm gonna make the first test pizza at the restaurant.

speaker: JERRY
words: You got a regular 'Manhattan Project' going on over there.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah. Anyway, he's about to leave, he wants the duck money. (Poppie enters.)

speaker: JERRY
words: Okay. Hi, Poppie.

speaker: POPPIE
words: Hello.

speaker: JERRY
words: I'm sorry about the gift, I didn't know about your condition.

speaker: POPPIE
words: That's fine. If you just give me my duck money, I'll be on my way.

speaker: JERRY
words: Okay. I'll get it. (Goes into the bedroom.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Why don't you sit down, Poppie? You're still recuperating. (Poppie moves to the sofa and sits down, and exhales a loud sigh of relief.) What, are you tired, Poppie?

speaker: POPPIE
words: No.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey, Poppie...you really think people wanna make their own pizza?

speaker: POPPIE
words: Kramer, did I ever tell you about my mother? My mother -

speaker: JERRY
words: Here you go. (Poppie stands up and takes the money.) Anyway, I'm sorry again about the...(notices a large, wet stain on his couch)...the...the...

speaker: POPPIE
words: The what? (Looks at Kramer, and exits.)

speaker: JERRY
words: ...the...the...

speaker: KRAMER
words: So long. I'll see you tonight.

speaker: JERRY
words: Kramer, Kramer, what is this?!

speaker: KRAMER
words: What is what?

speaker: JERRY
words: This puddle on my sofa!

speaker: KRAMER
words: What puddle?

speaker: JERRY
words: That puddle! (Kramer sees the puddle and does a double-take.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: I don't know.

speaker: JERRY
words: Is it...? Could it...? Could he have...? IT IS! (Grabs Kramer.) Poppie peed on my sofa!!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Are you sure?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, what is it then?! My new sofa! Poppie peed on my new sofa!

speaker: KRAMER
words: I'm sure it'll come out.

speaker: JERRY
words: I don't care if it comes out, I can't sit on that anymore!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Ah, you're making too much of it.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, you're right. It's just a natural human function...happens to be on my sofa, instead of in the toilet, where it would normally be.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Right!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, anyway, the book club meets tomorrow, Mr. Temple.

speaker: JOE
words: Well, I was going to watch it with my daughter. She likes Audrey Hepburn very much.

speaker: GEORGE
words: She was a delicate flower.

speaker: JOE
words: Why didn't you just read the book?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, as I say, the pink-eye made my vision...quite blurry... (Joe's daughter comes to the door.)

speaker: JOE
words: Remy, this is George. Would you mind if he watched Breakfast At Tiffany's with us? (George smiles at Remy. Remy looks at Joe doubtfully.)

speaker: CARL
words: Hi.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hi. (They kiss.)

speaker: CARL
words: I missed you.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, I missed you!

speaker: CARL
words: I don't remember the last time I felt this way.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Me, either!

speaker: CARL
words: I think about you all the time.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You do?

speaker: CARL
words: Do you think about me?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh yeah, all the time, all the time...although, recently I've been thinking about this friend of mine.

speaker: CARL
words: What friend?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, just this woman...she got impregnated by her troglodytic half-brother, and decided to have an abortion. (Waits in suspense for what Carl's response will be.)

speaker: CARL
words: You know, someday...we're going to get enough people in the Supreme Court to change that law.

speaker: GEORGE
words: So, anything to uh, nosh?

speaker: JOE
words: What did you want?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Popcorn?

speaker: REMY
words: Popcorn? Where do you think you are?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, a lot of people keep popcorn in the house.

speaker: REMY
words: Well, we don't.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You might want to try it...makes the movie more enjoyable, that's all.

speaker: JOE
words: Here's some nuts.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh! Nuts! Excellent! You know what I love? How there's two nuts named after people. Hazel...and filbert.

speaker: REMY
words: Can we watch the movie now, Daddy? (Joe presses play on the remote.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hey, let's turn off the lights, get some real 'movie atmosphere.'

speaker: JOE
words: The lights are fine. (George shrugs, and the movie begins.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: See, anybody can do this. (Tosses pizza dough into the air.)

speaker: POPPIE
words: Use your wrist! It's all in the wrist. (Kramer tosses the dough way up there.) Not too high!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Alright, put a little sauce on here... (speaks some unintelligible words in an Italian accent while spreading the sauce around.) Some cheese...

speaker: POPPIE
words: Not too much!

speaker: KRAMER
words: And...cucumbers! (Grabs a large handful and puts them on the pizza.)

speaker: POPPIE
words: Wait a second...what is that?

speaker: KRAMER
words: It's cucumbers.

speaker: POPPIE
words: No, no. You can't put cucumbers on a pizza.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, why not? I like cucumbers.

speaker: POPPIE
words: That's not a pizza. It'll taste terrible.

speaker: KRAMER
words: But that's the idea, you make your own pie.

speaker: POPPIE
words: Yes, but we cannot give the people the right to choose any topping they want! Now on this issue there can be no debate!

speaker: KRAMER
words: What gives you the right to tell me how I would make my pie?

speaker: POPPIE
words: Because it's a pizza!

speaker: KRAMER
words: It's not a pizza until it comes out of the oven!

speaker: POPPIE
words: It's a pizza the moment you put your fists in the dough!

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, it isn't!

speaker: POPPIE
words: Yes, it is!

speaker: JOE
words: Hey, honey.

speaker: REMY
words: Hi, Mom.

speaker: JOE
words: Yeah.

speaker: JOE
words: Aw, that's too bad.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Joe...could you...

speaker: GEORGE
words: You know, I'm sorry, I...I hate to be one of those people, but we're right in the middle of this thing...I can't hear.

speaker: JOE
words: This is George Costanza.

speaker: GEORGE
words: This is very hard to follow with all the talking.

speaker: JOE
words: I'll pause it, okay? (Pauses the tape with the remote.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Any more grape juice? (Gets up and goes to the kitchen. Remy moves to the end of the couch where George was sitting.)

speaker: REMY
words: He's in some book club.

speaker: REMY
words: Cheating on his test. (George returns from the kitchen with a glass of grape juice.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: So, we watching the movie, or are we still talking? (Joe's wife shakes her head and goes into the other room. George gestures to Remy to move.) Okay, c'mon. Let's go.

speaker: REMY
words: What?

speaker: GEORGE
words: C'mon, you took my seat.

speaker: REMY
words: It's not your seat.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I was sitting there, c'mon.

speaker: REMY
words: You didn't save it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I had the arm! Joe...

speaker: JOE
words: What's the difference?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, I was very comfortable! I've got my nuts here...

speaker: REMY
words: It's my couch.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Alright, c'mon, scooch over. (Tries to squeeze into the corner seat of the couch and struggles with Remy. He spills his glass of grape juice all over the couch in the process.)

speaker: REMY
words: Look! Look what you did! You got grape juice all over our couch, you've ruined our couch! (Joe slowly walks toward George with his hands on his hips.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Joe...

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh my god.

speaker: JERRY
words: You see?!

speaker: ELAINE
words: So, you're gonna get a new couch?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, I guess I have no choice.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Do you want your old couch back?

speaker: JERRY
words: I was hoping you'd offer. (The intercom buzzes, Jerry answers it.) Yeah?

speaker: INTERCOM
words: It's the movers.

speaker: JERRY
words: 'Kay. (Buzzes them in.)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Who's that?

speaker: JERRY
words: Your boyfriend, he's taking it out.

speaker: ELAINE
words: No, no, he's not my boyfriend.

speaker: JERRY
words: Why?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Take a guess.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, really. (Carl and another moving guy come in and pick up the couch.)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hi.

speaker: CARL
words: Hi.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey Carl, I also need you to go to Elaine's and bring my old couch back.

speaker: CARL
words: Today?

speaker: JERRY
words: Could you?

speaker: CARL
words: Sure.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What are you doing with this couch?

speaker: JERRY
words: George is taking it.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Did you tell him it was peed on?

speaker: JERRY
words: He said he doesn't care, he'll just turn the cushion over.

speaker: CARL
words: I'm sorry you feel that way, Elaine.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, me too.

speaker: CARL
words: It's just too bad.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah. It is.

speaker: CARL
words: Well, I better get this couch back to Jerry's.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Can I offer you anything to drink?

speaker: CARL
words: Yeah, sure.

speaker: ELAINE
words: All I've got is grape juice.

speaker: CARL
words: Throw it!

speaker: CARL
words: The couch!

speaker: MARIE
words: She didn't want the constraints of any relationship, that's why she got rid of the cat. The most important thing in Holly's life was her independence.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, not really. After all, she did get together with George Peppard. I mean, Fred.

speaker: MARIE
words: George...Fred's gay.

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: I've never been able to figure out why they make these bizarre toilet seats that they have. You know, like those clear Lucite ones, with all the, the coins in it? It's a lovely tribute to our past president, by the way. It's not bad enough Lincoln got shot in the head, we gotta pull down our pants and sit on him, too. It's just incomprehensible that you would buy a thing like this, you install it on your toilet seat, and this says what about you? "Well, I can't afford to just throw money down the toilet, but look how close I am!"

speaker: JERRY
words: I cannot believe Lindsay's still seeing you after that "Breakfast at Tiffany's" thing.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I think she finds my stupidity charming.

speaker: JERRY
words: As we all do.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah, anyway, she's uh, having some kind of a family lunch, I'll swing by after.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, so you're gonna meet the mother?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah, I'll zip in, "How do you do?", zip out. She'll love me.

speaker: JERRY
words: You're good with the mothers.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Y'know, I'm better with the mothers than I am with the daughters.

speaker: JERRY
words: Maybe you should date the mothers.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, if I could talk to the mothers and have sex with the daughters, then I'd really have something goin'.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, you got something goin'.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (enters apartment) Hey.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hey! (heads toward bathroom)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey, you got a hammer?

speaker: JERRY
words: What do you need a hammer for?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, I got this new poster. 3-D art? Computers generate 'em.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, yeah! I wanna see that. Bring it over.

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, no, I don't have it now. I gotta pick it up at Mr. Pitt's. Elaine was framing a bunch of stuff for him, so she did me a favor. What, you wanna take a ride?

speaker: JERRY
words: Nah, I don't think so.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (shouting to the bathroom door) George, you wanna go for a ride?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (inside bathroom) Nah.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, COME ON!

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, could you wait until the man finishes?

speaker: KRAMER
words: All right, I've had it with you two. (opens apartment door to leave)

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, guess what? Remember that woman you saw me with the other day? You know, she used to be an Olympic gymnast?

speaker: KRAMER
words: A gymnast!

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, she's Romanian, she won a silver at the '84 Olympics.

speaker: KRAMER
words: A gymnast, Jerry. Think of the flexibility. Mmm, that sex'll melt your face.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, well, I think I'm bailing.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (shuts door) "Bailing"?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, you know, Kramer, there's always a price to pay for just a sexual dalliance.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry, you should pay that price.

speaker: JERRY
words: She's Romanian. What am I gonna talk to her about, Ceausescu?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Ch- oo-... what?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (emerging from bathroom, buttoning his shirt) A gymnast! I can't believe it, you didn't tell me she was a gymnast.

speaker: JERRY
words: (watching George buttoning his shirt) What is this?

speaker: GEORGE
words: What, I'm puttin' my shirt back on.

speaker: JERRY
words: (stares at George, incredulous) "Back on"? What was it doing off?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I take it off when I go to the, uh, y'know, to the "office".

speaker: JERRY
words: (laughing) What for?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, it frees me up. No encumbrances.

speaker: JERRY
words: Unbuttoned, or all the way off?

speaker: GEORGE
words: ALL the way, baby!

speaker: JERRY
words: Of course.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (convulses in pain) Yeow! Whoa.

speaker: JERRY
words: What, again? Kramer, if you keep getting these attacks, you should see the doctor and have it checked out.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (exiting apartment) Yeah, yeah, yeah...

speaker: JERRY
words: (picks up newspaper, turns to George) You always take the shirt off?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Always.

speaker: JERRY
words: Boy, I tell ya', knowing you is like going out in the jungle. I never know what I'm going to find next, and I'm real scared.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Elaine, I need you to proofread this report for my meeting with the Poland Creek Bottled Water people.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What meeting?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I told you. I sit on the Board of Trustees for Morgan Springs, and we're trying to acquire Poland Creek.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh! (tries to take paper)

speaker: MR. PITT
words: (pulls away) Are you using a fountain pen?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yes?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: They smear! Under no circumstances is ink to be used in this office.

speaker: ELAINE
words: All right! I'll use a pencil, Mr. Pitt.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Elaine?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Come in, come in!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah. (enters, points at package) Yah, huh?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Ah, right there, yeah.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (rips open package) Yeah, that's...

speaker: ELAINE
words: Kramer, it's...

speaker: KRAMER
words: (holds up framed picture): There she blows! (throws paper around)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Kramer, Kramer, can you do this at home? I've got, I've got work to do, okay?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, these are nice corners, huh?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Elaine, did I hear... (sees Kramer) Oh, this is very odd.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (looking at picture) Yeah, it's 3-D art. Computers generate 'em. BIG computers.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Yes, I've heard about these. How do they work?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, you blur your eyes like you're starin' straight through the picture. And you keep your eyes unfocused. And then... (Kramer and Pitt stare at picture) Oh, oh, oh, YEAH!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I don't see it.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, it's a spaceship, surrounded by planets, asteroids...

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I still don't see it.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Okay, Kramer, that's enough. Mr. Pitt has got work to do.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Ya' ever dream in 3-D? It's like the boogeyman is comin' right at you.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: A spaceship, where?

speaker: KRAMER
words: (pointing) Right in here. Just keep your eyes unfocused. (convulses in pain) Waahh! Oh, mama!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Kramer, what's wrong?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Mama!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Kramer, Kramer, are you okay?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I think I gotta go to the doctor! (exits) Oh, mama!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: (still staring at picture) How long does it usually take?

speaker: MRS. ENRIGHT
words: Oh, George, it is so nice to finally meet you. And I'm sorry we've kept Lindsay so long.

speaker: LINDSAY
words: Mother...

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, no, no, not at all. No, I have always felt that the most important thing in the world is spending time with family.

speaker: MRS. ENRIGHT
words: Oh? Are you and your family close?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (hesitates) Very close, yes. Almost painfully close.

speaker: LINDSAY
words: Mother, I'm going to walk Nana and Aunt Phyllis to the elevator. George, do you mind waiting just one more minute?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Mind? Why would I mind? I would love to wait! (shakes hands with Nana) Nana, nice to see you. Ni-ni-ni-ni-NANA! (embraces another guest, kisses her) Aunt Phyllis, always a pleasure. What a pleasure! Hey, let's do this again real soon. I had fun, huh?

speaker: MRS. ENRIGHT
words: Can I offer you anything to eat?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, no no no, I'm fine. Let me help you with these dishes, huh?

speaker: MRS. ENRIGHT
words: Oh no, George, you don't have to...

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, I know I don't have to, I want to.

speaker: MRS. ENRIGHT
words: George, you are such a gentleman.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'd argue if I could, Mrs. Enright. (exits) Here we go, all right.

speaker: MRS. ENRIGHT
words: (wide-eyed) Oh...

speaker: GEORGE
words: (spits out mouthful of food): Mrs. Enright! Mrs. Enright!

speaker: ELAINE
words: (pointing at 3-D picture) Look, there's a spaceship! That is so cool!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Where is it?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (pointing) Right here.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I'm looking there!

speaker: ELAINE
words: No, no, unfocus.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I am unfocused!

speaker: ELAINE
words: (answering phone) Hello? Oh, yeah, okay fine. Uh, he'll be right down. (to Pitt) Car's here to pick you up and take you to the meeting.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: (still staring at picture) Meeting?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, the Poland Creek merger?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Why don't you go for me?

speaker: ELAINE
words: How can I go?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Oh, all they're gonna do is read the report.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Mr. Pitt, I do not think that is such a good idea.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Oh, DAMN this thing!

speaker: JERRY
words: (trying desperately to make conversation) So, Ceausescu. He must've been some dictator.

speaker: KATYA
words: Oh yes. He was not shy about dictating.

speaker: JERRY
words: He, uh, he must've been dictating first thing in the morning. "I want a cup of coffee and a muffin!"

speaker: KATYA
words: And you could not refuse.

speaker: JERRY
words: No, you'd have to be crazy.

speaker: KATYA
words: He was a very bad dictator.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yes. Very bad. Very, very bad.

speaker: JERRY
words: So lemme get this straight: you find yourself in the kitchen. You see an clair, in the receptacle. And you think to yourself, "What the hell, I'll just eat some trash."

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, no. No, no, no. It was not trash!

speaker: JERRY
words: Was it in the trash?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes.

speaker: JERRY
words: Then it was trash.

speaker: GEORGE
words: It wasn't down in, it was sort of on top.

speaker: JERRY
words: But it was in the cylinder!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Above the rim.

speaker: JERRY
words: Adjacent to refuse, is refuse.

speaker: GEORGE
words: It was on a magazine! And it still had the doily on.

speaker: JERRY
words: Was it eaten?

speaker: GEORGE
words: One little bite.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, that's garbage.

speaker: GEORGE
words: But I know who took the bite. It was her aunt!

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, you, my friend, have crossed the line that divides Man and Bum. You are now a Bum.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey.

speaker: JERRY
words: What's with you?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I got a stone.

speaker: JERRY
words: What stone?

speaker: KRAMER
words: A kidney stone.

speaker: JERRY
words: What is that, anyway?

speaker: KRAMER
words: It's a, it's a stony mineral concretion, formed abnormally in the kidney. And this jagged shard of calcium pushes its way through the ureter into the bladder. It's forced out through the urine!

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, that's gotta hurt.

speaker: ARONSON
words: Our shareholders have given basic approval for the merger, including the stock swap.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Ah. The "stock swap". Let's swap some stock. (giggles)

speaker: BECK
words: And if you'll just give this to Mr. Pitt, and tell him we expect to be in full-scale production by the spring.

speaker: ELAINE
words: All right. (standing up) Hey, you guys--what's the name of the new company gonna be?

speaker: BECK
words: Moland Spring.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (making a face) "Moland"?

speaker: ARONSON
words: Yes, we combined Morgan and Poland.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, I know, but... "Moland"? I wouldn't drink anything called "Moland".

speaker: ARONSON
words: But it was Mr. Pitt's idea.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh! Well, ah, what's in a name? I mean, water's water. Right?

speaker: ARONSON
words: (to Beck) We've got to do something about that name.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (on phone, as Jerry gestures beside him) No, Lindsay, it was not IN the garbage. It was above the garbage. Hovering. Like an angel. Of course I know your aunt bit it. I kissed her goodbye. Listen, can I tell you something else? In my family, we used to eat out of the garbage all the time. (Jerry makes a face) It was no big thing. That's right. Oh, okay. Buh-bye. (hangs up phone) I'm back in, she gave me a second chance.

speaker: JERRY
words: Good for you.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes, good for me!

speaker: JERRY
words: Y'know what you should do now? Get her some flowers, smooth it out.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes, flowers. I will get her flowers, I will go to the florist!

speaker: KRAMER
words: (enters apartment, holding up videotape) Behold! The Games of the '84 Olympiad! Katya's silver medal performance! (inserts tape into VCR, sets up TV)

speaker: JERRY
words: Kramer, are you still on this? I've seen gymnasts. I know what they do. It's not going to make any difference.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry, what is your problem?

speaker: JERRY
words: Kramer, y'know, guys like you, with no conscience, don't know what it's like for guys like me. I'm in the unfortunate position of having to consider people's feelings.

speaker: KRAMER
words: All right, Jerry--are you familiar with the Kama Sutra?

speaker: JERRY
words: No.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Tantric yoga?

speaker: JERRY
words: No.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry, you stand on the threshold to the magical world of sensual delights that most men dare not dream of!

speaker: JERRY
words: Boy, you can really talk some trash. (to George) I guess that's better than eating it.

speaker: KRAMER
words: All right, all right, why don't we just watch the tape? (starts playback)

speaker: JERRY
words: All right.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Did you pass your stone yet?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Not yet. But the suspense is killing me.

speaker: JERRY
words: (pointing at TV) Hey, that's her!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh yeah. Oh yeah, that's her. (feminine grunts and sighs can be heard as they watch the tape) Look at the height, Jerry, the extension! Now watch the tuck. Handstand, half-turn, giant into a straddle, back into another handstand. Nice kip. Reverse hecht. Oh, nice leg extension, good form! Now, here comes the big dismount. Look at the rotation, full in, double back, and she sticks the landing! (gets up to leave as George and Jerry continue to watch, mouths agape) Perhaps you'd like to keep the tape? (silence) Well, I'll take that as a yes.

speaker: JERRY
words: (smiling and excited) Well, here we are.

speaker: KATYA
words: Yes. We are here.

speaker: JERRY
words: How did you stay on that beam like that? (holds up hand) I mean, it's only this wide!

speaker: KATYA
words: I can balance myself in any position.

speaker: KATYA
words: It is amazing after years of training how one can contort one's body. Of course, it is only useful in gymnastics.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh boy...

speaker: JERRY
words: I couldn't believe it. Uh, I mean I thought I was entering a "magical world" of sensual delights, but it was just so ordinary. I mean, there was nothing gymnastic about it.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, what did you think she was gonna do?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, you know. I mean... I dunno.

speaker: ELAINE
words: No, what?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, obviously I prefer not to mention any, you know...

speaker: ELAINE
words: What did you think, she was going to take some of that chalk and...

speaker: JERRY
words: You see, now I really don't want to get into this, any kind of specifics...

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, come on. One thing? One thing! What?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well... Frankly, I thought, you know, I was gonna kinda' be like the apparatus.

speaker: KRAMER
words: You mean like the uneven parallel bars?

speaker: JERRY
words: See, again, I really don't feel that...

speaker: ELAINE
words: The balance beam?

speaker: JERRY
words: Could we stop?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (gasps in mock surprise) Not the pommel horse?

speaker: JERRY
words: All right. Let's just drop it.

speaker: JERRY
words: So lemme ask you this: how long would you say I have to put in now because of, you know, last night.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I dunno, at least three weeks.

speaker: JERRY
words: (sarcastic) Oh, great.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Jerry, that is such small potatoes. I think that I may have single-handedly put the kibosh on the big water merger.

speaker: JERRY
words: Between Poland and Morgan?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah. Started a big name controversy.

speaker: JERRY
words: Kramer! The stone!

speaker: JERRY
words: What happened, did you pass the stone?

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Off-screen) No, I tried to do a reverse hecht off my couch and I didn't make it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (singing as he exits florist with bouquet and a cup of coffee) "...tootsie, good-bye. Too-too, tootsie..." (takes a drink, makes a face, shouts back at shop) You call this coffee? (dumps out coffee behind him, accidentally hitting a parked car's windshield)

speaker: MAN IN CAR
words: Hey! What the hell was that?!

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'm sorry! I'm terribly sorry! I- I-

speaker: MAN IN CAR
words: Clean that up!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, sure. Of course. (looks for place to set down flowers) Um, uh, could you hold these? For just a second, just a second. (grabs newspapers from trash bin, begins wiping windshield) Here you go, now don't worry about a thing. It's gonna be fine. Here we go. Look at this shine.

speaker: MRS. ENRIGHT
words: (sees George cleaning car windshield, looks appalled)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Look at this sparkle. (looks up, sees Lindsay's mother) Mrs. Enright! (runs after her) Mrs. Enright! Mrs. Enright!

speaker: GEORGE
words: (on phone, as Jerry gestures beside him) No, Lindsay, I had accidentally spilled coffee on the gentleman's windshield. Why would I do that? I have a job! Well, did she see a squeegee? Well, you're not going to make a dime without a squeegee. That's right, that's right, just tell your mother it was all a big misunderstanding. You won't regret it. Okay, I'll see you later. Buh-bye. (hangs up)

speaker: JERRY
words: Strike two!

speaker: GEORGE
words: You think I'm going down?

speaker: JERRY
words: You're behind in the count.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I know.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (enters apartment, points at Jerry) Hey, what are you doing later?

speaker: JERRY
words: I'm going out with Katya, thanks to you.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, maybe you should try again. You know what happens the first time: people are a little shy, a little reticent.

speaker: JERRY
words: If I do it again, that extends my payment book another two weeks.

speaker: KRAMER
words: All right, where you going?

speaker: JERRY
words: We're going to the circus. One of her old Olympic teammates is an acrobat. I don't even feel like going out.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, Jerry, it's your obligation. C'mon.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, well, y'know what? If I gotta go, and spend time with this girl, then you're coming with me, Dr. Cyclops!

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, no, no, I don't wanna go to the circus, Jerry.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, well you're going.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, but I'm afraid of clowns!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: (in polo outfit, complete with jacket and high boots) I didn't send you over there to complain about the name.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I couldn't help it. "Moland Spring"?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I like the name "Moland". I picked it out. After all those months of negotiating!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I'm so sorry! I-

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Well, I'm going riding. I haven't been on Jenny for three days, all because of this blasted painting. (phone rings) Elaine?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, sorry. (picks up phone) Hello?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: (walks by 3-D poster, stops) Wait a minute! Wait a minute. Ah!

speaker: KATYA
words: So, Jerry, you're enjoying the circus?

speaker: JERRY
words: "Greatest Show on Earth"!

speaker: KATYA
words: My father used to take me to the circus. When the elephants came by, he would scream curses at them, blaming them for all the ills of society.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, they certainly take up a lot of space.

speaker: KATYA
words: Ah, Misha!

speaker: MISHA
words: Katya!

speaker: KATYA
words: Misha, this is Jerry.

speaker: MISHA
words: Ah, yes. The "co-me-dian", eh? (speaks in Romanian to Katya)

speaker: KATYA
words: (laughs, replies in Romanian while pointing at Jerry)

speaker: ELAINE
words: (on phone) Oh, yes, yes I'll tell him. Yes, thank you. Um, um hold on. (to Pitt) Mr. Pitt!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: (staring at 3-D poster) I think I'm on to something!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Mr. Pitt! The board of directors is on the phone. They've called an emergency meeting. They want you to be there to discuss the merger!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: You said keep your eyes out of focus, which is misleading. You want DEEP focus!

speaker: ELAINE
words: (on phone) Yes, hi. Okay, fine, yeah, hold on just a second. Lemme just... (reaches into purse) Yeah, I've got it... (pulls out both hands completely covered in black ink) Oh! Oh! Yeah, yeah, he'll be there. (drops phone, rushes to Pitt) Mr. Pitt, you have GOT to stop staring at that poster!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I see something that could be a spaceship. Is it round? Is it pointy?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (grabs poster, smashes it) No, you don't see it, and you're never going to see it! (grabs Pitt by the lapels, getting ink all over his jacket) Mr. Pitt, you have to meet with the shareholders, you have to leave now. Do you hear me? Do you hear me?!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Hmm, what's happened to me? (straightens lapels) When's the meeting?

speaker: ELAINE
words: In about twenty minutes.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Oh! (puts finger to face, smearing ink on his upper lip which now resembles an "Adolph Hitler"-style moustache) Do I have time to change?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Um, no.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Well, excuse me, I'd better get straight over there.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Uh, Mr. Pitt...

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Yes?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Um, there's a just... (points at her own upper lip)

speaker: MR. PITT
words: (sees Elaine's hands covered in ink) Is that ink?

speaker: ELAINE
words: No?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, here we are.

speaker: LINDSAY
words: Do you want to come in? My mother's having a little party.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Maybe I could just use the bathroom.

speaker: LINDSAY
words: Sure.

speaker: ANNOUNCER
words: (voiceover) Ladies and gentlemen, could I direct your attention to the center ring, where the incomparable Misha will balance ten stories above the circus floor on a wire no wider than a human thumb.

speaker: MISHA
words: It is time.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, break a leg.

speaker: JERRY
words: Eh, show biz...

speaker: ANNOUNCER
words: Ladies and gentlemen, the incomparable Misha!

speaker: JERRY
words: Boy, those capes are really coming back.

speaker: PARTY GUEST
words: (exits bathroom, finds George waiting) Oh, sorry I took so long. They've got one of those 3-D art posters in there. (wipes eyes) It's mesmerizing.

speaker: JERRY
words: What is that sound?

speaker: KATYA
words: (covering ears) It is horrible!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Whew! Anybody see that poster in there? That is weird, wild stuff, huh? Whew!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I have been accused of wrong-doing. But these false accusations will not deter us. We WILL annex Poland by the Spring, at any cost! AND... our stock will rise HIGH! (raises hand)

speaker: KATYA
words: He'll be all right. I must go and be with Misha now. I don't want you to come with me.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, why not?

speaker: KATYA
words: It has been three days since our night together. Misha said that was all the time I needed to put in.

speaker: JERRY
words: Really?

speaker: KATYA
words: In my country, they speak of a man so virile, so potent, that to spend a night with such a man is to enter a world of such sensual delights most women dare not dream of. This man is known as the "Comedian". You may tell jokes, Mr. Jerry Seinfeld, but you are no Comedian. (walks off)

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: I like the names they have for cars. Like, no baron has ever owned a LeBaron. Or the Ford LTD. "LTD." Limited. It's a "limited" edition...what did they make, fifty million of those? "Yes, it's 'limited' to the number we can sell." Or when they try and mangle a positive word into a car name, you know how they'll do that? The "Integra." Oh, integrity? No, Integra. The "Supra." Or the "Impreza." Yeah? Well, I hope it's not a "lemona"...or you'll be hearing from my "lawya."

speaker: CAR SALESMAN
words: George, are you sure I can't show you any other cars?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I don't think so, Vic. I've done my homework. '89 Volvo, that's the car for me, it's the one I want.

speaker: SALESMAN
words: I got a LeBaron convertible right here.

speaker: GEORGE
words: N.I. Not interested.

speaker: SALESMAN
words: It's got a few more miles on it, but the previous owner was John Voight.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jon Voight?

speaker: JERRY
words: Okay, Tim. You're welcome. (Hangs up.)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Was that Tim Whatley?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yes, it was. He wanted your address - you, my friend, are going to be invited to his night-before-Thanksgiving party. (Elaine raises her hands triumphantly, then gleefully struts her way to the kitchen.) You know, he's got that great apartment on 77th street, and they overlook where they inflate all those huge balloons for the Macy's Thankgiving Day Parade?

speaker: ELAINE
words: I have always had a big crush on Tim Whatley. Why can't he ask me out? (Punctuates this by shoving Jerry.)

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, he's a dentist. You don't want to go out with a dentist.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Why?

speaker: JERRY
words: He'll always be criticizing your brushing technique, it'll drive you crazy. (Mimics brushing his teeth) Away from the gums... (The door opens a little, George jangles the keys to his new car at Jerry and Elaine, then enters.)

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh - new car!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Ohhh!  Mark's Michelle is a dog.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey! Did you get the Volvo?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, I decided to go with an '89 LeBaron.

speaker: ELAINE
words: A LeBaron?

speaker: JERRY
words: I thought Consumer said Volvo was the car.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What Consumer? I'm the consumer.

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright. Seems like...a strange choice.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, maybe so...but it was good enough for Mr. Jon Voight.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Jon Voight? The actor?

speaker: GEORGE
words: That's right. He just happened to be the previous owner of the vehicle.

speaker: JERRY
words: You bought a car because it belonged to Jon Voight?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, no...

speaker: JERRY
words: I think yes, yes. You like the idea of telling people you're driving Jon Voight's car.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Alright, maybe I do. So what.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I've never even seen him in a car. I mean, look at his movies. No cars. Deliverance - canoe. Midnight Cowboy - boots. Runaway Train...runaway train. (Kramer enters.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry, you know that shoe repair place at the end of the block? Well, if they don't get some business, they're gonna have to shut down and make way for one of those gourmet coffee or cookie stores.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I like coffee.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I like (imitates Kramer) "cookies."

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, of course you do. And do you know why? Because you're a bunch of yuppies. It's your go-go corporate takeover lifestyles that are driving out these Mom and Pop stores and destroying the fabric of this neighborhood.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, what's so great about a Mom and Pop store? Let me tell you something. If my Mom and Pop ran a store, I wouldn't shop there.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey, Bogambo - they've been in the neighborhood for 48 years. Now, come on, Jerry. You've gotta have a pair of shoes in need of a cobblin.'

speaker: JERRY
words: I really don't wear the kind of shoes that have to be cobbled.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, what about sneakers? You know, they'll clean 'em. They do complete detailing.

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright, take 'em.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah-yah.

speaker: POP
words: Kramer, without you, we'd be out of business.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well you know, these sneakers, they belong to my neighbor, Jerry Seinfeld? The comedian.

speaker: MOM
words: So many sneakers!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, he's got a Peter Pan complex.

speaker: POP
words: They'll be ready a week from Thursday.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, well, no rush. (wipes his nose) Uh oh.

speaker: MOM
words: What's the matter?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, I keep getting these nosebleeds.

speaker: MOM
words: Oh, lie down, and put your head back.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah. (Lies on the couch and cracks the back of his head against the armrest.) Hey, what's with your ceiling? (Mom and Pop look up.)

speaker: POP
words: What?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, you got wires sticking out every which way. That looks dangerous, you should call the electrician.

speaker: POP
words: You know, in the 48 years we've been here, I don't think we've ever called an electrician.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah well, you should. This place could blow any minute.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Elaine?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yes, Mr. Pitt?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Have you gotten all the salt off those pretzels yet?

speaker: ELAINE
words: No, I'm still working on it.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: What in blazes are you listening to?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Artie Shaw. "Honeysuckle Jump." (The song ends.)

speaker: DJ ON RADIO
words: That was Artie Shaw, "Honeysuckle Jump."

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Elaine! How did you know that?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, my father used have a huge collection of big band records.

speaker: DJ ON RADIO
words: Congratulations to our listener Wayne Hopper for identifying it. And by doing so, he becomes our seventh person to land the WFBB-sponsored Woody Woodpecker balloon in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. (Mr. Pitt hears this and is intrigued; mouths the words "Woody Woodpecker.") There are only three spots left. We're going to take a little break now; when we come back, you'll have three more chances to win a spot holding a rope under Woody Woodpecker.

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Could you identify the next song? Could you? Could you?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Mr. Pitt, why would you want to hold onto the ropes on the Woody Woodpecker balloon?

speaker: MR. PITT
words: My father was a stern man. He forbad us to participate in any activities that he thought were associated with the common man. The Thanksgiving Day Parade was first on the list.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh. Alright, I'll do the best I can. (Turns up the radio.)

speaker: DJ ON RADIO
words: Alright, here we go for the next spot under the balloon. If you know the name of this song, call 555-BAND. (The music starts. Elaine listens intently.)

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Well, Elaine? Do you know it? What song is it?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Will you shut up? I can't hear!

speaker: MR. PITT
words: I'm sorry!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh! I've got it! It's "Next Stop Pottersville"! (Grabs the phone to call it in.)

speaker: MR. PITT
words: Goody! Yes! Yes! Yes! (Dances back and forth, elated) Next Stop Pottersville, Next Stop Pottersville! You are a genius!

speaker: GEORGE
words: You are gonna love this car. Even if you don't like Jon Voight.

speaker: JERRY
words: I like Jon Voight. Just seems like kind've a strange reason to buy a car, because he might have driven it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What do you mean "might"? You don't think he really owned this car?

speaker: JERRY
words: I don't know.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, why would the guy make up something like that? Of all the names he could pick, why settle on Jon Voight?

speaker: JERRY
words: Don't you see, that's the genius of it. If he had said Liam Neeson, you'd know he's making it up.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Neeson? How are you comparing Liam Neeson with Jon Voight? Jerry, we're talking about Joe Buck. If you can play Joe Buck, Oskar Schindler's a cake walk. (Opens the car door for Jerry, Jerry's about to get in.)

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, look at this, I stepped in gum.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Whoa, whoa, you're not getting in my car with gummy shoes.

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright, I'll change my shoes. (Heads back to his apartment. George follows.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Liam Neeson. You know, he's not American.

speaker: JERRY
words: Let me get a clean pair. (Goes into his room. George strides over to the window.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Everybody's talkin' at me...I can't hear a word they're sayin'...just drivin' around in Jon Voight's car...

speaker: JERRY
words: Kramer! (We hear Kramer's door slam open and shut. Kramer enters. Jerry comes out of his room.) Hey! Where's all my sneakers?

speaker: KRAMER
words: You said take 'em.

speaker: JERRY
words: Not all of 'em!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, obviously there was a miscommunication.

speaker: JERRY
words: Obviously. So what am I supposed to wear?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry, I left you a pair right here...(goes into Jerry's room and comes out with a pair of cowboy boots.) C'mon. There, put on those boots.

speaker: JERRY
words: I can't wear these!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, why not?

speaker: JERRY
words: They're uncomfortable.

speaker: KRAMER
words: C'mon here, try 'em on. (Jerry sits down and puts the boots on.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Where did you get those?

speaker: JERRY
words: I worked a club in Dallas one time and they couldn't afford to pay me so they gave me these. Oh, I can't wear these! (Stands up.) They look ridiculous!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Ah, you look like a cowboy! Huh?

speaker: JERRY
words: But I don't wanna be a cowboy!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, stop it. You know that friend of yours, Tim the dentist? I got an invitation to his Thanksgiving Eve party.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah, I got one too.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah?

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh yeah? Huh.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What?

speaker: JERRY
words: No, nothing.

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, what is it?

speaker: JERRY
words: No, it's just that I, uh...didn't get one.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You didn't get one?

speaker: JERRY
words: Ah, but he called me up and he asked for yours and Elaine's addresses, I'm sure that means I'm invited.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Not necessarily.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, why would you call someone up and ask them for two addresses if you're not invited to the party?

speaker: GEORGE
words: That's the genius of it.

speaker: JERRY
words: I'm callin' Elaine. See if she can find out anything from Tim Whatley.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hey. I got Jon Voight's LeBaron. (Jingles the keys.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Boss!

speaker: POP
words: Four thousand dollars? We can't afford that!

speaker: ELECTRICIAN
words: Well I'm afraid you're gonna have to do something about it, because it's in violation of the building code. Otherwise, they're gonna close you up.

speaker: POP
words: But what if we can't pay for it?

speaker: ELECTRICIAN
words: Then I have to report you. Otherwise, I lose my license. Sorry. (Exits.)

speaker: POP
words: 48 years, Mom! And now we have to close! All because of that idiot and his bloody nose! (Kramer enters.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Afternoon, Mom! Afternoon, Pop. You know you got a crack in the sidewalk out there? Now, you oughta get that fixed.

speaker: GEORGE
words: So?

speaker: JERRY
words: C'mon, put the top up, it's November!

speaker: GEORGE
words: I feel alive, Jerry.

speaker: JERRY
words: Let's check out the glove box. (Opens the glove compartment, takes out a pencil.) Ah. Pencil.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hey...you don't think...sure, that's Jon Voight's pencil!

speaker: JERRY
words: With Jon Voight's teeth marks. (Looks at the owner's manual.) Owner's manual...you know what? This car was owned by Jon Voight.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Ah! See? I told ya.

speaker: JERRY
words: Except Jon is spelled with an H. J-O-H-N.

speaker: GEORGE
words: So?

speaker: JERRY
words: Doesn't Jon Voight spell his name J-O-N?

speaker: GEORGE
words: So, what are you saying?

speaker: JERRY
words: Nothing. I'm sure "Jon" probably mispelled his own name. I know sometimes I spell Jerry with a G...and an I! (Laughs uproariously.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Get out of the car!

speaker: JERRY
words: What?

speaker: GEORGE
words: That's right, you heard me. Get out! You are ruining this whole experience for me!

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, look! There's Gregory Peck's bicycle!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Get out!

speaker: JERRY
words: And Barbara Mandrell's skateboard!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Get out!! (Jerry gets out and George drives away. A couple of guys notice Jerry in his cowboy boots.)

speaker: TOUGH GUY
words: Hey, cowboy. Where's your horse? (Jerry slips and slides in his cowboy boots and runs away.) Yeah, you better run!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Did they take anything?

speaker: JERRY
words: No, they didn't even touch me. I tripped because of these stupid cowboy boots.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Anyway, again, I'm sorry about throwing you out of the car.

speaker: JERRY
words: You really seemed to enjoy it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: It was kinda fun. (Elaine gives Jerry a cold cloth for his jaw.) You know, maybe his name really is J-O-H-N, but he changed it to J-O-N for show business. Well, you know, J-O-N is a lot zippier.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, that's possible.

speaker: GEORGE
words: How would you find out something like that...wait a minute, what am I thinking? I've got the entire Yankee organization at my disposal.

speaker: JERRY
words: He'll dispose of it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Heh, that's right. See ya later. (Exits.)

speaker: ELAINE
words: So Jerome, I did a little snooping around for you.

speaker: JERRY
words: Ah! What'd you find out, Lois?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I talked to Tim Whatley...

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah...

speaker: ELAINE
words: And I asked him, "Should Jerry bring anything?"

speaker: ELAINE
words: Mmmm...and he said, "Why would Jerry bring anything?"

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright, but let me ask you this question.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What?

speaker: JERRY
words: Which word did he emphasize? Did he say, "Why would Jerry bring anything?" or, "Why would Jerry bring anything?" You emphasize "Jerry" or "bring."

speaker: ELAINE
words: I think he emphasized "would."

speaker: JERRY
words: You know what? The hell with this party, I don't even want to go to begin with. (Kramer enters.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, so where's my sneakers?

speaker: KRAMER
words: That's what I wanna know.

speaker: JERRY
words: What do you mean?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, I saw Mom and Pop this morning, but when I went by the store on my way home? The place was empty. Everything is gone. Mom and Pop - vrooop - vanished.

speaker: JERRY
words: So all my sneakers are gone?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I'm afraid so. And that's just the tip of the iceberg. I've been asking around - they didn't even have any kids.

speaker: JERRY
words: Mom and Pop aren't even a Mom and Pop?!

speaker: KRAMER
words: It was all an act, Jerry. They conned us, and they scored, big time.

speaker: ELAINE
words: So. Mom and Pop's plan was to move into the neighborhood...establish trust...for 48 years. And then, run off with Jerry's sneakers.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Apparently.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Alright, that's enough of this.

speaker: JERRY
words: Where ya goin'?

speaker: ELAINE
words: I gotta go to the Dixieland Deli to pick up Mr. Pitt's security pass for the parade.

speaker: JERRY
words: Why does he want to hold a rope underneath Woody Woodpecker in the Thanksgiving Day Parade?

speaker: ELAINE
words: He finds his laugh "intoxicating." (Laughs like Woody Woodpecker, and exits.)

speaker: MR. MORGAN
words: So George, what kind of promotional events are we talking about?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, I think we need more special days at the stadium, you know? Like, uh...Joe Pepitone Day. Or, uh...Jon Voight Day.

speaker: MR. MORGAN
words: Jon Voight? The actor? (Rubs his eyes wearily.) Uh, I make a motion that we have no more of these meetings that have been initiated by George Costanza.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I suppose if I had suggested Liam Neeson Day, you'd all be patting me on the back.

speaker: CONTEST WINNER
words: I guessed Stan Herman's "Boomtown Blues." What'd you guess?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Um, it was, uh..."Next Stop Pottersville." (The group is unimpressed.) Uh, do you know when they're giving out the passes?

speaker: CONTEST WINNER
words: After the music. (The band starts playing directly behind Elaine. She is deafened by the loudness of the horns.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh. Oh man. (Takes out a Kleenex and puts his head back. Jon Voight comes out of a doorway and hails a cab.)

speaker: VOIGHT
words: Taxi! (Walks right by Kramer.) Taxi.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey! Jon Voight! Jon Voight! (Voight waves at Kramer and hurriedly gets in the cab. Kramer runs over to the car.) Hey, listen, can I ask you something? Listen, listen...(Leans in the the open back window of the cab. Defensively, Voight grabs Kramer's arm and bites it. Kramer screams. The cab speeds off leaving Kramer in the street, stunned.)

speaker: JERRY
words: No Jon Voight Day, huh?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No. Now I'll always have this doubt about the car. What, your jaw still hurts?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, it's all swollen. I think I may have chipped a tooth when I fell yesterday.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You should have somebody take a look at that.

speaker: JERRY
words: I'm calling dentists all day here, there's nobody working the day before Thanksgiving.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You going to the party?

speaker: JERRY
words: No, I don't know if I'm invited.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, there's going to be a lot of dentists there.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, you're right.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You don't want to suffer with this all weekend.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, I gotta see a dentist, this is killin' me. Well, I'll take a chance. We'll go together.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Maybe I'll just meet you there.

speaker: JERRY
words: You don't want to go with me?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jerry, for all I know this guy went out of his way to not invite you. How am I gonna feel if I show up with an uninvited, unwelcome intruder?

speaker: JERRY
words: The way I feel when I go places with you? (Kramer enters.) Hey, so'd you find my sneakers yet?

speaker: KRAMER
words: No. (To George) But I did run into somebody you might be interested in, a Mr. Jon Voight, the actor?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jon Voight! Are you kiddin' me? Did you talk to him?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, he was a little standoffish.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What, you didn't ask him about the car?

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, I couldn't, his cab pulled away. But he did, however, make an impression on me. (Pulls up his sleeve and shows George his arm.) Look.

speaker: JERRY
words: What?

speaker: KRAMER
words: His tooth marks. He bit me.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jon Voight bit you?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, what is he, a vampire?

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, it's justifiable. He thought I was going for his wallet.

speaker: GEORGE
words: He left perfect imprints.

speaker: KRAMER
words: That he did. Now, you got that pencil with the bite marks on it? We get a trained eye to match 'em up, and we'll see whether or not you're driving Jon Voight's car!

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, please.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Wait a minute, wait, it's not that stupid.

speaker: JERRY
words: No, it's stupid.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Why? Why isn't it possible? I mean, they're both bite marks.

speaker: JERRY
words: So you're gonna show up at that party with a chewed-up pencil and Kramer's gnarled arm.

speaker: GEORGE
words: It's worth a shot. (Goes to the door.)

speaker: JERRY
words: So, Kramer, you wanna go to the party together?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry, look, come on, I'm an invited guest. I can't be aiding and abetting some...party-crasher.

speaker: JERRY
words: Excuse me, uh...dentist? You a dentist? (The guy shakes his head. Jerry moves on to another guy.) Dentist? Are you a dentist?

speaker: GEORGE
words: These are the balloons? Big deal, all I see is Woody Woodpecker.

speaker: KRAMER
words: You got a problem with Woody Woodpecker?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah, what is he? Some sort of an instigator?

speaker: KRAMER
words: That's right. He's a troublemaker.

words: Hey, Elaine. Did you get my message?

speaker: ELAINE
words: What? I can't hear a word you're saying. I was stuck at the Dixieland Deli all day. My head is still ringing. Where's Tim?

speaker: JERRY
words: What is that, the Empire State Building?

speaker: ELAINE
words: What? I can't hear you.

speaker: JERRY
words: Elaine, would you marry me?

speaker: ELAINE
words: I told you, I can't hear a word.

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright. Forget it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hey, Tim.

speaker: TIM
words: Hey, George. Kramer, how ya doin.' (They shake hands.)

words: Watch the arm! Tim, listen, we don't want to bother you, we know you're busy here.

speaker: TIM
words: No, it's no problem, what is it?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Let me show you something, take a look at this... (Another guy at the party interrupts.)

speaker: GUY
words: Alright Tim, I'm gonna get goin.'

speaker: TIM
words: Alright, let me take down your number. (Grabs George's pencil, then notices Jerry sitting on the couch.) Is that Jerry Seinfeld?

speaker: KRAMER
words: He didn't come with us. (Tim walks over to Jerry.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Uh, Tim, the pencil...

speaker: TIM
words: Jerry.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, Tim.

speaker: TIM
words: Jerry. I didn't think you'd show.

speaker: JERRY
words: Did you say, "Jerry, I didn't think you'd show" or, "Jerry, I didn't think you'd show"? (Elaine comes over.)

speaker: TIM
words: Elaine! Hi!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Tim.

speaker: TIM
words: Well. I'm really glad you came.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What?

speaker: TIM
words: Really glad you came.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Uh huh.

speaker: TIM
words: Listen, Elaine, I've been wanting to ask you...would you like to go out with me New Years Eve? (Elaine thinks Tim is offering her a nut, and shakes her head no. Tim, rejected, walks away.) Thanks.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What? What?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Let me ask you something. Could you tell if teeth marks on someone's arm matched teeth marks on a pencil?

speaker: DENTIST
words: It's possible.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Roll up your sleeve.

speaker: DENTIST
words: Somebody bit you?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Not just someone. Jon Voight.

speaker: DENTIST
words: Jon Voight bit you? (George notices Tim across the room with the pencil in his mouth.) The pencil! Hey, hey! Get the pencil out of your mouth, you're destroying Jon Voight's teeth marks!

speaker: TIM
words: That's John Voight's pencil?

speaker: GEORGE
words: That's right. I got his whole car downstairs.

speaker: TIM
words: Are you the one who bought his LeBaron convertible?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes! Yes, I'm the one! Hey! So, you know Jon Voight!

speaker: TIM
words: Yes! Yes, I went to dental school with him.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jon Voight, the actor?

speaker: TIM
words: No. The periodontist. (George snaps the pencil in two.)

speaker: DENTIST
words: Can't this wait until Monday? Come by my office.

speaker: JERRY
words: Just a quick peek. I'm in agony.

speaker: DENTIST
words: Alright. Sit down.

speaker: JERRY
words: It's this one here in the back. (Tilts his head back, and knocks Elaine's trophy out the window. A loud hissing sound and commotion is heard from the street below. Everyone runs to the windows to look.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh! You popped Woody Woodpecker!

speaker: TIM
words: Hey, who invited you, anyway? You're a troublemaker! (Jerry nervously laughs like Woody Woodpecker as the breeze from the popped balloon blows in the window.)

speaker: ANNOUNCER ON TV
words: Hey, it looks like Woody Woodpecker is running out of air. In fact, he's collapsing.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Those kids look pretty disappointed.

speaker: JERRY
words: Especially that big kid up in the front. (Mr. Pitt is shown on the television, trying to hold up the deflating Woody balloon.) How old is he? (The phone rings.) Hello?

speaker: GUY ON PHONE
words: Hello, is this Jerry Seinfeld?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yes it is.

speaker: GUY ON PHONE
words: You don't know me, but a really strange thing happened. I was at a garage sale, and this old couple sold me a used pair of sneakers they claimed belonged to Jerry Seinfeld, the comedian.

speaker: JERRY
words: Can I have the address of that garage sale? Okay, thank you very much. (To Kramer) I found Mom and Pop, they're sellin' my sneakers!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Where are they?

speaker: JERRY
words: Parsippany, New Jersey.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Let's go!

speaker: JERRY
words: My car's in the shop.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, how are we getting to Parsippany?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Uh. Jerry. These nosebleeds are starting again.

speaker: JERRY
words: Maybe we should get you to a hospital.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey, I ain't goin' to no Bellevue! Look at me, I'm fallin' apart here.

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY

words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: (unwrapping a piece of gum) I think gum is, is one of the weirdest human inventions. (pops gum in his mouth) It's not a liquid, 's not a solid, 's not a food. What is it? It isn't really anything, you know. I mean, it's like a stationary bike for your jaw. Like, remember when you were in school, and teachers would get all riled up if they caught you with gum? And when you were a kid, you'd think 'What is the big deal?' But, as an adult, I can understand it, because when you're chewing gum, you don't look like you're too thrilled with anything anyone has to say. (as sarcastic teen) 'Oh, World War Two. That was an important historical event? Yeah, I'm sure.' 'They landed a man on the moon, nineteen sixty-nine? Yeah, right. Yeah, I buy that, teach.'

words: Swinging? What are you, out of your mind? Look at you, you're

words: But she's an anti-Semite.

words: Can you blame her?

speaker: HELEN
words: You don't think he minds us staying here, do you?

speaker: MORTY
words: Why would he mind? We're his parents.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh.

speaker: HELEN
words: Hi Elaine.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hello. Jerry's not here?

speaker: HELEN
words: No.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Huh. (pause) Oh my god.

speaker: HELEN
words: What?

speaker: ELAINE
words: A poppy seed! It must have been in the chicken. Oh, I'm dead. I'm

speaker: HELEN
words: Why?

speaker: ELAINE
words: It's a long story.

words: Just a second, I have to go to the bathroom.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What are you gonna do in there?

speaker: HELEN
words: What am I gonna do in the bathroom?

speaker: ELAINE
words: You gotta do me a favor.

speaker: HELEN
words: Elaine, I really--

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hold on a second. Mrs. Seinfeld, I need your sample.

speaker: HELEN
words: You want my urine?

speaker: ELAINE
words: I need a clean urine sample from a woman.

speaker: HELEN
words: I don't know.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh please, Mrs. Seinfeld, please?

speaker: HELEN
words: Well, what am I gonna do it in?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, one of those glasses.

speaker: HELEN
words: Jerry's glasses?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, he won't mind. C'mon, you're his mom.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, a coffee cup's fine.

speaker: HELEN
words: Or maybe a juice glass.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yes, fine, fine, a juice glass is perfect.

speaker: HELEN
words: This one is kind of scratched.

speaker: ELAINE
words: It doesn't matter.

speaker: HELEN
words: Howbout A milk glass.

speaker: ELAINE
words: A milk glass, a juice glass, any glass, just pick a glass.

speaker: HELEN
words: Jerry doesn't wash these very well.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Mrs. Seinfeld, pick a glass! Pick a glass, Mrs. Seinfeld!

speaker: SALESMAN
words: All right, I got everything here. I got the Cyclone F series, Hydra

speaker: JERRY
words: What do you recommend?

speaker: SALESMAN
words: What are you looking for?

words: Power, man. Power.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Like Silkwood.

words: That's for radiation.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: That's right.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Now, what is this?

speaker: SALESMAN
words: That's the Commando 450, I don't sell that one. What about thi-

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well that's what we want, the Commando 450.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: We'll pay anything. We've got the (hands a wad of money to Kramer)

words: He couldn't handle that, he's delicate.

words: It's nice being back at Leo's Jerry's place was too small.
