words: First Leo breaks up, then he goes back. What the hell's going on?

speaker: MORTY
words: Who is it?

speaker: SUPER
words: It's the super. We're installing new low-flow showerheads in all the

speaker: MORTY
words: Low flow? I don't like the sound of that.

speaker: PETERMAN
words: So as a result of your test being free of opium, I am reinstating you.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh! Yes! What a load off. So when are we going to Africa?

speaker: PETERMAN
words: I'm afraid I can't take you.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What? Why not?

speaker: PETERMAN
words: Elaine, according to your urine analysis, you're menopausal. you

speaker: ELAINE
words: But I wanted to see the bushmen.

speaker: PETERMAN
words: Oh, and one more thing. You may have osteoporosis.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, it's been a great visit.

speaker: MORTY
words: Jerry, I'll tell ya. The first thing I'm gonna do when I get back to

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, at least the Costanzas changed their mind and decided not to move.

speaker: HELEN
words: George must be happy about that.

speaker: JERRY
words: You have no idea.

speaker: FRANK
words: Take my swim trunks. I won't need them.

speaker: ESTELLE
words: What does he want with your swim trunks?

speaker: FRANK
words: Why should they go to waste?!?

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: Thank you! Goodnight! (Walks off stage, sighing deeply. Instantly, a red-headed woman runs up and hugs him - taking Jerry by surprise)

speaker: SALLY
words: Jerry!

speaker: JERRY
words: (Trying to ward her off) Hey. Hey!

speaker: SALLY
words: (Reminding him who she is) Sally Weaver! (Sees Jerry's expression - he still has no clue who she is) Susan Ross' roommate from college.. hello! (Laughs slightly)

speaker: JERRY
words: Right.. Oh, I'm sorry. Uh, oh, so you saw the show?

speaker: SALLY
words: Saw it? I loved it! And thank you for the free tickets. You are so funny.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Modest) Oh, thanks.

speaker: SALLY
words: (Serious) No, no, I mean it. You're very funny.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Blunt) I believe you.

speaker: SALLY
words: Oh, anyway, let me show you Memphis. I am taking you (Points to him) out to dinner.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Grabbing his coat) Oh, I'm sorry, I can't - I'm going straight to the airport.

speaker: SALLY
words: Ohh.. that's too bad.. Susan thought we'd really get along - I guess because we're both wacko! (Jerry laughs) You know what, um.. (Turns around, picking up a large gift from a table) You have to give this to them for me. Okay? Here. (Hands the box to Jerry, he struggles under the size of it) It's a wedding present.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh?

speaker: SALLY
words: And Jerry? Be careful with it, okay? Be very careful.

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh-huh.

speaker: FRANK
words: George, as you may be aware, your mother and I are not moving to Del Boca Vista, Florida.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Resenting the fact. Nodding) I am aware.

speaker: FRANK
words: So, I was wondering, would it be okay if I turned your room into a billiard parlor?

speaker: GEORGE
words: A billiard parlor?

speaker: FRANK
words: Regulation table, the hi-fi, maybe even a bar.. Give it real authenticity..

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, that's.. Elaine!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, hi, Frank.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Sliding over to make room for her) Sit down. Join us, please.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Trying to come up with an excuse not to sit with them) Actually, I gotta get to the.. uh.. thing.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Somewhat stern) Oh, the thing's cancelled. Sit down.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Giving up) Okay.. (Sits, George laughs) So.. (Trying to think up something to talk about) Frank, did George ever show you that photo?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Confused) What photo?

speaker: ELAINE
words: You know, the photo I took in Tuscany of the little man in front of the sign that said "Costanza"?

speaker: FRANK
words: (Interested) There's a Costanza in Tuscany? (Elaine nods) Did he look like me? Did you talk to him?

speaker: ELAINE
words: I didn't talk to anyone - I was just walking by, and I saw the sign, and I thought George might get a kick out of it.

speaker: FRANK
words: I gotta get that picture - it could be my cousin, Carlo.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Who is that?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Muttering out, not really wanting to talk about his family) When the Costanzas came here, one brother stayed behind.

speaker: FRANK
words: I played with him every day until the age of four - and then we separated.

speaker: ELAINE
words: So, you weren't born here?

speaker: FRANK
words: No. That's why I can never be president.. It always irked me. That's why, even at an early age, I had no interest in politics. I refuse to vote. (Yelling out) They don't want me, I don't want them!

speaker: GEORGE
words: I don't know what you're getting all riled up about. There are probably a million Costanzas-

speaker: FRANK
words: (Cutting him off) Don't bring me down. (To Elaine) Do you have another copy of that photo?

speaker: ELAINE
words: No, I, I don't. But.. Well, the Maestro might.

speaker: FRANK
words: The Maestro? What Maestro?

speaker: ELAINE
words: He's this guy that I went to Tuscany with. He's a great guy, but I just wouldn't feel comfortable calling him.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Really? Why?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Explaining) Because he hasn't called me since we got back.. I spilled wine on his 8 by 10 photo of one of his favorite Italian opera stars.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Who?

speaker: ELAINE
words: You know the Three Tenors?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah.. (Trying to remember) Poverotti.. Domingo.. and.. uh.. the other guy.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Nodding) The other guy.

speaker: STEWARDESS
words: (Overly nice) Could I take that box for you?

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh.. well, you better not. I'm supposed to be careful with it.

speaker: STEWARDESS
words: Oh, then, I'll have to put your bag in the over-head.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, okay..

speaker: STEWARDESS
words: There we go.

speaker: JERRY
words: Ohh.. look at this..

speaker: KRAMER
words: What?

speaker: JERRY
words: I bought a bottle of BBQ sauce in Memphis. I think the stewardess broke it when she tried to jam it into the overhead compartment because of this (Gestures to Sally's present) stupid thing.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, don't press the panic button. I'm sure that we can still salvage some sauce..

speaker: JERRY
words: I don't care about the sauce. It came in this funny little bottle, and there was a guy on the label that looked exactly like Charles Grodin.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Taking some of Jerry's clothing over to the kitchen) I see..

speaker: JERRY
words: No, you don't see - because I'm going on the show this week, and this was going to be my bit on the show.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, why don't you do your material?

speaker: JERRY
words: I'm out.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Looking up, sighs) Well, you better get to work.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Sarcastic) Thanks for the tip.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hey, buddies.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey. Hey, this is for you. (Taps the gift) It's from.. uh, Susan's roommate, Sally.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh yeah.. (Starts to open it) Sally called Susan - said you guys really hit it off.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Annoyed at the thought) Nobody hit anything off. She just gave me the box. (Looks over at Kramer. He is scraping the BBQ sauce off Jerry's clothes with a knife, then dipping some bread into it) What the hell are you doing?

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Looks up) I'm salvaging the sauce. What's the matter with you? (Eats the bread)

speaker: JERRY
words: (Pleading) Hey, hey, hey. Come on, come on.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Moving out into the living room) Jerry, why don't you do a bit on Styrofoam?

speaker: JERRY
words: Like what?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, uh.. (Starts to impersonate Jerry's act) "What is this stuff? Why do we need this stuff?.. And why do they make it so small..?"

speaker: JERRY
words: (Confused) Where's the punchline?

speaker: KRAMER
words: It's all attitude.. (Makes a humorous face - mocking Jerry's)

speaker: GOERGE
words: (Taking out a mat from the huge box) Well, this is certainly a crappy gift..

speaker: JERRY
words: A door mat? That's what she had me lug up from Memphis?!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Pretty chintzy, huh? Considering the money she makes.. She's a big executive for Federal Express.

speaker: JERRY
words: Federal Express?! Is she out of her mind? Why didn't she just ship it?!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Look, it's personalized. (Holds it up, reading) "The Costanzas"

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, no. Forget it. I don't want it. Let's just get rid of it.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, maybe your father would be interested in that.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I doubt it. You know what he's doing now? He's putting a pool table in my old bedroom.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Interested) Oh yeah? Well, maybe I'll go out there and knock a few balls around with him. You know, show him a thing or two..

speaker: KRAMER
words: So, what's your game? What do you like to play?

speaker: FRANK
words: Eight ball.

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, nothing doing. Let's, you and me, play a game of straight pool.. hmm?

speaker: FRANK
words: You like to gamble, Cosmo?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, now and then - you know how it is..

speaker: FRANK
words: Five dollars a game, huh?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I'll break.

speaker: FRANK
words: Okay.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What's all this?

speaker: SUSAN
words: Oh, I'm just moving in some more of my stuff.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Muttering to himself as he walks to the bedroom) More stuff..

speaker: SUSAN
words: (Calling out) Oh, I put up my doll collection..

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh my God! What is that?!

speaker: SUSAN
words: (Rushing in) What? What is it?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Staring at the doll) This doll (Pointing) looks like my mother.

speaker: SUSAN
words: George, it's a doll.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I know it's a doll, but it looks like my mother!

speaker: SUSAN
words: (Going back to the living room) Oh, get outta here..

speaker: ESTELLE
words: What's going on in here? (Kramer hits the cue ball, it jumps up from the table and flies off screen) Are you two still playing?! You've been up here three hours!

speaker: FRANK
words: We still haven't finished the first game.

speaker: ESTELLE
words: The first game?!

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Explaining why they are doing so bad) Well, we're still, uh, learning the subtleties of the table.

speaker: FRANK
words: (To Estelle) he knows the Maestro. He could have the picture..

speaker: ESTELLE
words: Oh, forget about it. It's not your cousin.

speaker: FRANK
words: (Yelling out) You don't know that! (Estelle leaves, slamming the door) We're gonna go see him, huh?

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Judging up his next move) As soon as the game is over..

speaker: FRANK
words: (Sensing the game is going to last a long time) Oh boy.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Eleven, corner pocket. (Pulls back on his stick, accidentally crashing it into the window)

speaker: GEORGE
words: What is this thing doing here?

speaker: SUSAN
words: Oh, I used to love to sleep with my dolls when I was a little girl..

speaker: GEORGE
words: Uh, I'm sorry, I can't do this..

speaker: SUSAN
words: Why?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I feel like I'm in bed with my mother.

speaker: SUSAN
words: Oh, stop it.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, Elaine, you have got to buy this new electric toothbrush I just got - the Ori-dent.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Just making conversation) Oh yeah?

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, it's unbelievable. Every time you use it you feel like you just came from the dentist!

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Mock enthusiasm) Oh, that's dynamite.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, what are you doing tomorrow? You want to come see me on the Charles Grodin show?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Who else is on the show?

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh.. one of the three tenors.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Interested) The Three Tenors? (Stands up) Which one?!

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh.. It's not Poverotti.. It's not Domingo..

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Extremely excited) The other guy?!

speaker: JERRY
words: (Nodding) Yeah, the other guy.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Screams out in joy) My God! I can't believe the other guy's going to be on the show!

speaker: JERRY
words: Why?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Because I ruined this autographed picture of him that belonged to the Maestro. You think I can go and get his autograph?

speaker: JERRY
words: Why not?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Extremely giddy) Wow! The other guy!

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, you look awful.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Sitting on the sofa) I'm on no sleep, bro.

speaker: JERRY
words: Problem in the bedroom?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Muttering) Susan has the doll collection.. one of the dolls looks exactly like my mother.. she likes to sleep with it.

speaker: JERRY
words: Wow. You were in bed with your mother last night?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Long pause) ..Felt like it. I tell you, this doll is pretty spooky. (Takes off his glasses, rubbing his eye) It's freakin' me out man. And now I got to go back out there and pick up this doormat.

speaker: JERRY
words: I thought you didn't want the doormat.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I don't. Susan wants to have it out when Sally comes tomorrow.

speaker: JERRY
words: Sally? (Getting upset) Wait, wait a minute - She's coming to New York?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah, (Smiling) Susan said you'd be excited.

speaker: JERRY
words: Excited? I'm gonna kill her! She knew she was coming here and she made me carry that box?!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Who's Sally?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Susan's college roommate.

speaker: JERRY
words: It's because of her that bottle got broke that I was going to give to Charles Grodin on his show.

speaker: GEORGE
words: So call her up and tell her to bring you another one. She'll be delighted to talk to you.

speaker: JERRY
words: (While opening a cereal box) I will - don't worry. (Plotting revenge) In fact, I'll have her bring up a whole case of the stuff. It'll be really heavy. Let's see if she likes sitting on a plane with a big box on her lap!

speaker: ELAINE
words: That's sounds pretty juvenile.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Pulling out the toy from the cereal box - he displays even more immaturity by holding it up, smiling) Hey! A dinosaur!

speaker: FRANK
words: His name was Carlo Costanza. We played together everyday until I was four. If I could just look through your photographs, maybe I could recognize him.

speaker: MAESTRO
words: Unfortunately those photographs are at home.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, listen, if you bring 'em by, maybe we could interest you in a game of pool.. Yeah, Frank here - he's got his own billiard room.

speaker: FRANK
words: (Trying to concentrate) Yes, It's, uh, it's.. uh, uh.. What do you call it, Kramer?

speaker: KRAMER
words: A billiard room.

speaker: FRANK
words: No, not billiard.. (Scolding) Not billiards.. it was.. Come on, already. Come on..

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Confused) What?

speaker: FRANK
words: We call it.. the, uh..

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Snaps) The Place To Be!

speaker: FRANK
words: The place to be! Yes! It's the place to be.

speaker: MAESTRO
words: (Agreeing to a game) Ah, then I shall be there. And now, Gentlemen, (Making dramatic actions) if you will excuse me - I must prepare for the symphony.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, yeah?

speaker: MAESTRO
words: (Noticing the expressions) Ohh, my pants. (Begins putting on a near-by pair of pants) It's an old conductor's trick I learned from Leonard Bernstein.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Really?

speaker: MAESTRO
words: You keep a perfect crease by not sitting in them before the performance.

speaker: KRAMER
words: That's good thinking.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You see?.. You see?!

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, it doesn't look exactly like her.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jerry, come on. If my mother keeps shrinking, this is exactly what she's gonna look like in ten years!

speaker: JERRY
words: Why don't you just get rid of it?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I tried! I almost threw it down the incinerator, but I couldn't do it. The guilt was too overwhelming. (Grabs the doll, opening the door to leave) Susan's so attached to this thing.

speaker: JERRY
words: Wait, where are you going? Don't take your dolly and go home.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hi, Elaine.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Did you see that?!

speaker: JERRY
words: I'm just glad it's outta here. (Elaine exhales deeply - getting over the scare of the doll. She moves into the apartment) What's that? (Pointing to a rolled up poster Elaine is carrying)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, it's a poster of the three tenors.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh. (Intercom buzzes, Jerry answers it) Yeah?

speaker: SALLY
words: (Through the intercom) It's Sally.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, did you bring the bar-b-que sauce?

speaker: SALLY
words: A whole case.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Letting her up) Excellent. (To Elaine) So, did you buy that electric toothbrush I was telling you about?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Blunt, to the point) No.

speaker: JERRY
words: How come? I told you - It's fantastic.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Eh, I like mine.

speaker: JERRY
words: I've had yours, I'm telling you - this one is ten times better. Don't you believe me?

speaker: ELAINE
words: I don't want it.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Slightly confused by her behavior) I don't understand this. Why wouldn't you want to get something that's better if I'm telling you it's better? And it's not a little better - it's much better.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Not committing to the conversation) It doesn't matter to me.

speaker: JERRY
words: Come in.

speaker: SALLY
words: (Peppy) Well, here I am!

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, hi. Elaine, this is Sally.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hi.

speaker: JERRY
words: How was your flight? (Wishful thinking) Pretty uncomfortable?

speaker: SALLY
words: (Setting the box down on his table) Actually, the seat next to me was empty, so, there was no problem at all.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Let down) Oh.. (Starts to open the box) Oh, wait.. (Holding up one of the BBQ jars) This isn't the sauce that I asked for!

speaker: SALLY
words: That's right. It's a special gourmet sauce. "The Pride of Memphis!"

speaker: JERRY
words: (Complaining) No, no. I wanted the one in the little bottle with that guy on it that looks like Charles Grodin!

speaker: SALLY
words: This is much better. And frankly, in Memphis, we think that other sauce as (Whispering) kind of a joke.

speaker: JERRY
words: I know it's a joke. It's supposed to be a joke! Now I'm going on the Charles Grodin Show with nothing. (Sets the jar down angrily) Nothing!

speaker: SALLY
words: You could just do your material.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Peeved) I don't have any material!

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Yelling out) He's got nothin'!

speaker: DOLL
words: Georgie! Don't eat with your hands! (George starts eating faster) Why do you eat so fast?! You can't even taste it!

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Losing it) Don't tell me how to eat!

speaker: DOLL
words: You're wearing that shirt? You've had it for five years already! Why don't you get a new shirt?!

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Trying to keep it down) Because I like this one! (Notices people staring at him, he quickly gets up, collecting the his coat and the tiny replica) C'mon, let's go. Let's go! (On his way out, he stops in front of a woman blocking his path) Oh, hi.. (Embarrassed about the doll, he sheepishly walks out)

speaker: WOMAN
words: (To Ruthie, the cashier) That man should really be in a sanitarium. (Ruthie nods, agreeing)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Now this is remarkable. I'm lounging, and yet, my pants remain perfectly creased.

speaker: FRANK
words: It's him! (Standing up) It's Carlo Costanza!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Come on. Are you sure?

speaker: FRANK
words: I'd know him anywhere.

speaker: MAESTRO
words: I've seen that man in Tuscany. Eccentric fellow. Reputation of being kind of a village idiot.

speaker: FRANK
words: I still say we're related.

speaker: MAESTRO
words: (Recognizing the currently playing song) Ohh, I love this piece. (Turns it up, then pantomimes that he is conducting the instruments)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Alright, come on Frank. It's your shot.

speaker: FRANK
words: (Complaining) I can't make anything..

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Like a professional) Well, that's because you don't know how to follow through correctly.

speaker: FRANK
words: Follow through? What do you mean?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Right here, come on, I'll show you.. (Gets behind Frank, holding the pool stick with him) Take hold of your stick.. alright, bring it back slowly..

speaker: FRANK
words: It's a little unnatural, but I think I'm getting the hang of it.

speaker: ESTELLE
words: Oh, my God!

speaker: JERRY
words: (Still ticked off) That woman is such an idiot! I was gonna do this whole bit on that bottle - and now I got nothing to talk about.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, have you ever considered writing new material?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, maybe if I didn't have so many people in my apartment all the time I'd be able to get some work done.

speaker: ELAINE

speaker: GEORGE
words: George is going to the movies! (exits)

speaker: JERRY
words: (to Kramer) So how's your karate class going?

speaker: KRAMER
words: (pronouncing it "kar-ah-tay") Karate, Jerry. Karate. The lifetime pursuit of balance and harmony.

speaker: JERRY
words: ...But with punching and kicking.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry, karate is not here (pointing to the ground). It's here (points to head), and here (points to chest), and here (makes a circle with his hands).

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright, I gotta go to the airport to pick up Elaine.

speaker: KRAMER
words: What, she's been away?

speaker: JERRY
words: She's been in Mexico for six weeks.

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, I really think you're wrong. We just went to the fireworks the other day.

speaker: JERRY
words: That was July 4th!

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright, I'm outta here, and when I get back, I don't want to see you here (points to kitchen), here (points to living room), or here (makes similar circle with his hands).

speaker: ELAINE
words: It was unbelievable. Six weeks of traveling through Mexico all on Peterman's peso.

speaker: JERRY
words: Wow. So did you get any good ideas for the catalog?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, tons!

speaker: JERRY
words: Anything you couldn't have gotten tearing open a bag of Doritos and watching Viva Zapata?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (laughs sarcastically) You don't respect my work at all, do you?

speaker: JERRY
words: No, I don't.

speaker: ELAINE
words: So what's been going on around this dump? How's your fiancee?

speaker: JERRY
words: My what?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Jeannie... your fiancee.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, yeah, that. Well...

speaker: ELAINE
words: All right. Spill it, Jerome.

speaker: JERRY
words: There's really not that much to tell.

speaker: JEANNIE
words: See ya.

speaker: JERRY
words: See ya.

speaker: JERRY
words: (continuing) No rejection, no guilt, no remorse.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You've never felt remorse.

speaker: JERRY
words: I know, I feel bad about that...

speaker: ELAINE
words: I bet your parents were upset, huh?

speaker: JERRY
words: Eh.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You haven't told them yet, have you?

speaker: JERRY
words: No.

speaker: DUGAN
words: "So I pressed through the rushes, there below me, the shimmering waters of Lake Victoria..."

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: Oh, for the love of God, man! Just tell me what the product is.

speaker: DUGAN
words: It's a, uh, washcloth.

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: No washcloths!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, Mr. Peterman, I've got a really good idea for a hat. It combines the spirit of old Mexico with a little big city panache. I like to call it the Urban Sombrero.

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: (rubbing his neck) Oh, my neck is one gargantuan monkey fist.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Are you okay, Mr. Peterman?

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: Yes, yes. Go on, go on, go on.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, see, it's... businessmen taking siestas. You know, it's the, uh, the Urban Sombrero.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Mr. Peterman?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (inhales deeply) I tell you, Jerry, I'm feeling something. Something I haven't felt in a long time.

speaker: JERRY
words: Pride?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No. Autonomy, complete and total autonomy.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, you're your own boss now.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I wanna go to a tractor pull.

speaker: JERRY
words: Go ahead.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I am staying out all night!

speaker: JERRY
words: Who's stopping you?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I wanna bite into a big hunk of cheese, just bite into it like it's an apple.

speaker: JERRY
words: Whatever.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh God.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What?

speaker: JERRY
words: It's Dolores.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Who?

speaker: JERRY
words: Mulva.

speaker: DOLORES
words: Jerry, hi.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hi, Dolores. George, you remember Dolores?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Dolores!

speaker: DOLORES
words: Hi. (to Jerry) I heard you got engaged.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yes, Dolores, I did. It didn't work out, though, Dolores.

speaker: DOLORES
words: Oh, that's too bad. You know... we should get together sometime. See ya.

speaker: JERRY
words: See ya.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Bye, Dolores.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I thought Mulva hated you.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, so did I. You know what? I bet it was the engagement. I've shown I can go all the way.

speaker: GEORGE
words: All the way?

speaker: JERRY
words: Not our "all the way", their "all the way." I got the stink of responsibility on me.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah, and you were engaged for like a minute, I was engaged for a year.

speaker: JERRY
words: You stink worse than I do!

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'm feeling something else here, Jerry!

speaker: SECRETARY
words: Elaine, it's Mr. Peterman on the phone.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (answers the phone) Hello, Mr. Peterman, how are you feeling?

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: Elaine, I'll be blunt. I'm burnt out. I'm fried. My mind is as barren as the surface of the moon. I can run that catalog no longer.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What? Well, who's gonna do it?

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: What about you?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Me? Why me?

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: Why, indeed.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Mr. Peterman, you can't leave.

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: I've already left, Elaine. I'm in Burma.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Burma?

speaker: J. PETERMAN
words: You most likely know it as Myanmar, but it will always be Burma to me. Bonne chance, Elaine. (to a passerby) You there on the motorbike! Sell me one of your melons! (runs after him)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Mr. Peterman?

speaker: JERRY
words: Where?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Burma.

speaker: JERRY
words: Isn't it Myanmar now?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Jerry, he wants me to run the catalog! It's crazy! I can't be in charge!

speaker: JERRY
words: No, certainly not.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I mean, I can't give people orders!

speaker: JERRY
words: No one's gonna listen to you.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I am not qualified to run the catalog!

speaker: JERRY
words: You're not qualified to work at the catalog.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey. (notices Elaine) What's wrong?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, Peterman ran off to Burma, and now he wants me to run the catalog.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Where?

speaker: JERRY
words: Myanmar.

speaker: KRAMER
words: The discount pharmacy?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I'm just gonna tell him no. I can't run the catalog.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Whoa, whoa. Can't? When did that word enter your vocabulary? What, is the job too difficult? (Jerry nods) What, you don't have enough experience? (Jerry shakes his head) Oh, you're not smart enough? (Jerry shakes his head) Where's your confidence? (Jerry shrugs his shoulders) Look, Elaine, let me tell you a story. When I first studied karate...

speaker: ELAINE
words: Karate?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, karate. I had no support. Not from him, not from Newman, no one. The first time I sparred with an opponent, I was terrified. My legs, they were like noodles. But then I looked inside, and I found my katra.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Katra?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, your spirit, your, uh, being. The part of you that says, "Yes, I can!"

speaker: JERRY
words: Sammy Davis had it.

speaker: KRAMER
words: So I listened to my katra and now (vreep) I'm dominating the dojo. I'm class champion.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, you know, I, I have watched Peterman run the company.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Sure you have.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I know how to do it. Pair of pants, a stupid story, a huge markup. I can do that.

speaker: KRAMER
words: You follow your katra, and you can do anything. (leads her to the door) Now get out of here.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (excitedly) Okay.

speaker: KRAMER
words: That kid is gonna be all right.

speaker: JERRY
words: No, she's not.

speaker: JOEY
words: Come on, Kramer!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hey there.

speaker: JOEY
words: Come on. Mom's down in the car.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Okay, Joey.

speaker: JERRY
words: You guys both have class at the same time?

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, we're in the same class.

speaker: JERRY
words: What do you mean you're in the same class?

speaker: KRAMER
words: He almost beat me.

speaker: JERRY
words: Kramer, you're fighting children?!

speaker: KRAMER
words: We're all at the same skill level, Jerry.

speaker: JERRY
words: He's nine years old! You don't need karate, you can just wring his neck!

speaker: KRAMER
words: I got carpool. (exits)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Thanks for the juice box, Mrs. Z.

speaker: JOEY
words: Hey, could we stop for ice cream on the way home, mom?

speaker: MRS. ZANFINO
words: Mmm, I don't know...

speaker: MRS. ZANFINO
words: All right.

speaker: DUGAN
words: *You're* taking the job?

speaker: ELAINE
words: You got that straight. Now I want four new ideas from each of you by 6:00. No, make that six ideas by 4:00. All right, let's move, move, move, move, move!

speaker: SENSEI
words: Are you prepared for kumite?

speaker: SENSEI
words: Fight stance.

speaker: SENSEI
words: Hydjama! Begin!

speaker: SENSEI
words: (raising Kramer's arm) Winner!

speaker: GEORGE
words: It's open!

speaker: GEORGE
words: (surprised) Rosses.

speaker: MRS. ROSS
words: Hello, George.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, uh... come in, come, come in. (frantically clears the couch of newspapers and crumbs)

speaker: MR. ROSS
words: We, uh, tried to call, but the line was busy.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh. Oh. Yeah, sure. Here. Uh, sit down. Uh, uh, cheese, there? (he grabs a suit jacket from the desk chair and puts it on)

speaker: MRS. ROSS
words: We know the last three months have been hard on you.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, yes, yes, yes. Very, very hard.

speaker: MR. ROSS
words: And they've been hard on us, too. It's a terrible tragedy when parents outlive their children.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes, I agree. I hope my parents go long before I do.

speaker: MR. ROSS
words: That's why we decided to create a foundation to preserve Susan's memory.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, that's wonderful.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes, inte-- h-how inte-- how integral?

speaker: MR. ROSS
words: You'll be on the board of directors.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (feigning excitement) Great, great. O-Oh, oh, oh, gosh. You know, it's just... my duties with the Yankees...

speaker: MRS. ROSS
words: Don't worry, George. The foundation will revolve around your schedule. Evenings, weekends, whenever you have free time.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I can't believe this is happening.

speaker: MR. ROSS
words: Well, it wouldn't have without your friend Jerry's inspirational words. He said to us, "She's not really dead if her shadow is..." Uh, w-what was it, dear?

speaker: MRS. ROSS
words: Something about a way, a-and a light, uh... ha. Who the hell knows?

speaker: MR. ROSS
words: Well, what's important is that your relationship with Susan doesn't have to end.

speaker: MRS. ROSS
words: So will you be sure to thank Jerry for us?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (feigning happiness) The second I see him.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hey. How's your day, good?

speaker: JERRY
words: Actually, yeah. I'm meeting Mulva here in a few minutes.

speaker: GEORGE
words: So uh... Wrath of Khan, huh?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah. Was that a beauty or what?

speaker: GEORGE
words: What was that line again? Something about finding your way in a shadow?

speaker: JERRY
words: No, no, no, it's... "She's not really dead if we find a way to remember her."

speaker: GEORGE
words: That's it. That's the line... (squirts mustard into Jerry's coffee and stirs it) ...that destroyed my life.

speaker: JERRY
words: (stares into coffee cup and looks back at George) Problem?

speaker: GEORGE
words: The Rosses have started up a foundation, Jerry, and I have to sit on the board of directors.

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, board of directors. Look at you!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah! Look at me! I was free and clear! I was living the dream! I was stripped to the waist, eating a block of cheese the size of a car battery!

speaker: JERRY
words: Before we go any further, I'd just like to point out how disturbing it is that you equate eating a block of cheese with some sort of bachelor paradise.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Don't you see? I'm back in.

speaker: JERRY
words: All because of Wrath of Khan?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes!

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, it was the best of those movies.

speaker: GEORGE
words: KHAN!

speaker: WYCK
words: George.

speaker: WYCK
words: George. (taps him on the shoulder)

speaker: GEORGE
words: (startled) Oh!

speaker: WYCK
words: I'm Wyck Thayer, chairman of the Susan Ross Foundation.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Wink.

speaker: WYCK
words: (correcting him) Wyck.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Wyck.

speaker: WYCK
words: Now, as you know, the Rosses had considerable monies.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh. I know they have some monies.

speaker: WYCK
words: They had more than some monies. Many, many monies. And they planned to give a sizable portion of their estate to you and Susan after the wedding.

speaker: GEORGE
words: So, if Susan and I had... I mean, if the envelopes hadn't, uh... then we--

speaker: WYCK
words: Yes.

speaker: GEORGE
words: And now?

speaker: WYCK
words: Not. It's all been endowed to the foundation, even this townhouse.

speaker: GEORGE
words: This townhouse?

speaker: WYCK
words: This would have been your wedding gift.

speaker: GEORGE
words: And now?

speaker: WYCK
words: Not.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Not.

speaker: WYCK
words: Also endowed. George... I know how much Susan meant to you. It can't be easy.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You know, it really can't.

speaker: MULVA
words: So who broke it off?

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, that's the thing. It was completely mutual.

speaker: MULVA
words: Oh, come on. Everybody knows there's no such thing as a mutual breakup. Tell me the truth.

speaker: JERRY
words: I am. It was the world's first.

speaker: MULVA
words: You know, when I heard you got engaged, I thought *maybe* you had matured. But obviously there's no growth here. (exits)

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, I can't argue with that, but the fact remains... I was completely... (to himself, cursing her) Mulva!

speaker: JERRY
words: (answering) Hello?

speaker: SECRETARY
words: Please hold for Elaine Benes.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, I don't believe this.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (picking up) Jerry!

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hey. Guess who just finished laying out her first issue of the J. Peterman Catalog.

speaker: JERRY
words: How's it look?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (muffled, as she's smoking a cigar) It's a peach.

speaker: JERRY
words: Huh?

speaker: ELAINE
words: I say, it's a peach.

speaker: JERRY
words: Elaine, let me ask you something. When I told you my breakup was mutual, did you believe me?

speaker: ELAINE
words: No, no, no. It's weak. No one's gonna buy it, and you shouldn't be selling it.

speaker: JERRY
words: I gotta do some research here.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Hey, hey. Me. Talking. You know, between you and me, I always thought Kramer was a bit of a doofus, but he believed in me. *You* did not. So as I see it, he's not the doofus. *You* are the doofus.

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, I'm the doofus?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah. You, Jerry, are the doofus.

speaker: JERRY
words: You know, it occurs to me that Kramer is at karate right now.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, well, maybe I'll just go down there and thank him in person.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, that's what I was thinking.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Kramer!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, hey.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What are you doing?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, well, I-I-I'm dominating.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You never said you were fighting children.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, it's not the size of the opponent, Elaine, it's, uh, the ferocity.

speaker: ELAINE
words: This is what you used to build me up? This is where you got all that stupid katra stuff?

speaker: KRAMER
words: No, no. That's from, uh, Star Trek III... The Search for Spock.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Search... for Spock?!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, I know Jerry will tell you that The Wrath of Khan is the better picture, but for me, I always...

speaker: ELAINE
words: (pushes him) You doofus!

speaker: JERRY
words: Okay, question #8. What if I told you my fiancee left me for another man? Does that make me more likable, less likable, as likable? Let's start over here this time.

speaker: RUTHIE
words: Same.

speaker: WILLIE
words: Are we about through here?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I thought you said your mom was meeting us in the alley.

speaker: JOEY
words: She had a little change of plans.

speaker: KRAMER
words: What's going on? Hey, Timmy, Clara. That was some kind of workout we had tonight, huh?

speaker: GIRL
words: Now we finish it.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Aah! Aah! Mama!

speaker: JERRY
words: (on the phone) Dad, I wouldn't eat anything you caught in that pond out in front of the condo.

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh, look, Elaine's here, I gotta get going. Oh, by the way, uh, I'm not getting married. Tell mom. Bye. (hangs up)

speaker: JERRY
words: So... did you stop by the dojo?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yep.

speaker: JERRY
words: How's your confidence level?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Shot.

speaker: JERRY
words: Self-esteem?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Gone.

speaker: JERRY
words: Doofus?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (raises her hand) Yo.

speaker: JERRY
words: All right, so what? You put out the catalog. How bad could it be?

speaker: JERRY
words: What is that?

speaker: ELAINE
words: It's the Urban Sombrero. I put it on the cover.

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, nobody sees the... cover.

speaker: KRAMER
words: God!

speaker: JERRY
words: What happened to you?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Whew! I got whooped. You should have seen the rage in their little eyes. And those tiny little fists of fury. Oh. (notices the Urban Sombrero) What is that?

speaker: JERRY
words: It's the new cover of the J. Peterman Catalog. It is Elaine's choice. Let's congratulate her.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh I see. (Elaine walks up to him) Woof!

speaker: ELAINE
words: (pointing a finger accusingly at Kramer) You! This is all your fault! You told me I could run the company!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, then I was way off!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I'll see ya... (exits)

speaker: JERRY
words: Vaya con dios.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (with his forehead in his hands) Man, I gotta go lay down. You and George going out a little later?

speaker: JERRY
words: No, he's still stuck at the foundation.

speaker: KRAMER
words: You know, you oughta go down there and help him out. He's a widower.

speaker: JERRY
words: Widower? Wait a second. (goes to a notebook of his research)

speaker: WYCK
words: Okay, let's see. The beachhouse. 48 acres... ooh. Southampton. That should fetch a fair price.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Would I have had access to that?

speaker: WYCK
words: Of course, it would have been yours.

speaker: GEORGE
words: And now?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (anticipating the answer) Not.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hello?

speaker: JERRY
words: Hey, Georgie! I'm doing some research down at the coffee shop. Your story's the one.

speaker: GEORGE
words: My story?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, your widower story's tested through the roof. (various patrons give the thumbs up in approval) When are you getting out of there?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Uh, excuse me, Wyck. Uh, are we, uh, almost done here?

speaker: WYCK
words: (chuckling) Oh, no, not even close.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (remorsefully) I can't go.

speaker: JERRY
words: What do you mean you can't go? There's two really girls sitting at the counter eating grilled cheese. Cheese, George! Cheese!

speaker: WYCK
words: Okay, next item. Susan's doll collection. Estimated value: $2.6 million. What do you say we go through this doll by doll?

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: GEORGE
words: You want me to find a poem about Susan? May she rest in peace?!

speaker: WYCK
words: Well, we think it would be a nice touch for the Foundation literature. Do you have a favorite poet, George?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I like, uh...(mutters something unintelligible under his breath.)

speaker: WYCK
words: Pardon?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (mutters it again)

speaker: WYCK
words: Well, you should choose the poem since you knew Susan best at the time of her unfortunate (clears his throat)...accident.

speaker: JERRY
words: He cleared his throat?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes!

speaker: JERRY
words: So?

speaker: GEORGE
words: He did it right as he said "her unfortunate accident."

speaker: JERRY
words: Not getting it.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jerry, a throat-clear is a non-verbal implication of doubt - he thinks I killed Susan!

speaker: JERRY
words: Oh, help me, Rhonda.

speaker: GEORGE
words: What time is it?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Right now?

speaker: JERRY
words: I gotta go meet Pam.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, the bookstore girl. How's that goin'?

speaker: JERRY
words: Okay. I'm just not ga-ga over her. For once I'd like to be ga-ga.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Where's Elaine?

speaker: JERRY
words: She's having Carol, Gail and Lisa over. You know they all have kids now?

speaker: GEORGE
words: What's with all these people having babies?

speaker: JERRY
words: Perpetuation of the species.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah! Right!

speaker: JERRY
words: By the way, just for the record -

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, I did not! (They exit the coffee shop.)

speaker: CAROL
words: ...but because it comes out of your baby, it smells good!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, that's...that's sweet.

speaker: GAIL
words: Being a mother has made me feel so beautiful.

speaker: CAROL
words: Elaine, you gotta have a baby!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, hey, you know...I had a piece of whitefish over at Barney Greengrass the other day...

speaker: LISA
words: Elaine. Move to Long Island and have a baby already.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I really like the city.

speaker: CAROL
words: The city's a toilet. When's the last time you saw my little Adam?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Uh, it was in the Hamptons.

speaker: CAROL
words: Oh! I have pictures!

speaker: ELAINE
words: No, no, that's okay, it's uh...

speaker: CAROL
words: Look at him! Just look at him!

speaker: JERRY
words: So, Elaine was telling me about this piece of whitefish she had the other day...

speaker: GEORGE
words: Do you really think I'm wrong about this Wyck guy?

speaker: JERRY
words: You know, if you really want to test him out, why don't you try the old Jerry Lewis trick?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Jerry Lewis?

speaker: JERRY
words: I heard that when Jerry Lewis left a meeting, he'd purposefully leave a briefcase with a tape recorder in it. Then after five minutes, he'd come back for it and listen to what everyone said about him.

speaker: GEORGE
words: That's pretty paranoid.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yes, it is.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I like it!

speaker: JERRY
words: I thought you might.

speaker: PAM
words: Oh, hi! I'm Pam. You must be Kramer. (Kramer is smitten with Pam and grins goofily.) Jerry's told me a lot about you. (Kramer continues grinning.) Well, I'm supposed to meet Jerry, it's my day off. I work in a bookstore.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Books. (Knocks over a bowl of fruit on the counter.)

speaker: PAM
words: Oh, careful! (Jerry enters.)

speaker: JERRY
words: Hi, sorry I'm late.

speaker: PAM
words: That's okay. Kramer let me in.

speaker: JERRY
words: You know, if we rush, we can still make the movie.

speaker: PAM
words: Okay. (Touches Kramer's hand) It was really nice meeting you.

speaker: KRAMER
words: I'm in trouble, buddy. I just met a woman.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Go on.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, she's Jerry's girlfriend.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Ah, yes. Forbidden love.

speaker: KRAMER
words: She works in a book shop. Her name is Pam.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: "Pam." I don't know the woman, but she sounds quite fetching.

speaker: KRAMER
words: I can't even speak in front of her. (Sits down on the couch.)

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Jerry! What could she possibly see in Jerry? (Walks in front of Kramer and trips over his feet.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: She has delicate beauty.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Jerry wouldn't know delicate beauty if it bludgeoned him over the head.

speaker: KRAMER
words: And yet, he's my friend.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: And therein lies the tragedy. For I believe, sadly for you, that there is but one woman meant for each of us. One perfect angel for whom we are put on this earth.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Aw, that's beautiful, Newman.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: One winsome tulip we ceaselessly yearn for throughout our dreary, workaday lives! And you, my friend, have found your angel. I can tell. For my heart has also been captured by a breathless beauty - whom I fear I will never possess.

speaker: KRAMER
words: I thought we were talking about me.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Right. Kramer, you have to confront Jerry.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Confront Jerry? I can't.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: You must!

speaker: KRAMER
words: I won't!

speaker: NEWMAN
words: You will!

speaker: ELAINE
words: "Elaine, ya gotta have a baby." Ugh.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Where are all the poetry magazines?

speaker: ELAINE
words: The New Yorker has poetry.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes. The New Yorker.

speaker: JERRY
words: Why do you invite these women over if they annoy you so much?

speaker: ELAINE
words: They're my friends, but they act as if having a baby takes some kind of talent.

speaker: JERRY
words: C'mon, you want to have a baby.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Why? Because I can?

speaker: JERRY
words: It's the life force. I saw a show on the mollusk last night. Elaine, the mollusk travels from Alaska to Chile just for a shot at another mollusk. You think you're any better?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yes! I think I am better than the mollusk!

speaker: KEVIN
words: I couldn't help overhearing what you were saying.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, I'm sorry.

speaker: KEVIN
words: No, no, I think I agree with you. I mean, all this talk about having babies.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, like you must procreate.

speaker: KEVIN
words: Besides, anyone can do it.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, it's been done to death. (smiles)

speaker: GEORGE
words: I, uh, should have a poem very soon now.

speaker: WYCK
words: Are you okay, George?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, no, not really. Ever since Susan passed on, I have good days and bad. (Turns the briefcase towards the woman on his left.) Some days, I'm haunted by one word - why. Why Susan? Why wasn't it me licking those invitations? Why am I still here? Well, I gotta run. (Gets up and leaves the meeting.)

speaker: WYCK
words: ...and the stock options for this year look quite, uh... (George returns and retrieves the briefcase.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: Briefcase. (Shrugs and exits.)

speaker: ELAINE
words: So, Kevin. If I don't want children, does that make me a bad humanitarian?

speaker: KEVIN
words: Not at all.

speaker: ELAINE
words: 'Cause, I mean, when you get to know me, you'll see that I'm a pretty good humanitarian. (Waitress comes to the table and pours more coffee.) You are doing a wonderful job, by the way. Thanks a lot. (To Kevin) Right? Am I right? (Kramer walks by.) Kramer. Kramer! Come here, look at my new friend Kevin. (Kramer and Kevin shake hands.) Oh, you got a little, uh...

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, I just had two double-fudge sundaes.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh. Are you alright?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, I'll be okay.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You know, Jerry has one of those every time he bombs on stage.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, I'm sure he'll be sharing his next one with Pam.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, no...that won't last.

speaker: KRAMER
words: What do you mean?

speaker: ELAINE
words: He's not ga-ga.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Lemme tell you something, that Jerry Lewis? You wonder how some of these people get to the top? It's ideas like this! Brilliant! Hah-hah! (Notices that the briefcase is damaged.) Look at this - what the hell happened? The whole side is damaged here...and the lock is broken.

speaker: JERRY
words: How long did you leave it up there?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Five minutes. What the hell happened here?

speaker: JERRY
words: Play the tape, maybe we'll get a clue.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I have to rewind it first. (George presses the rewind button on the tape recorder. He and Jerry stand there, waiting impatiently as it rewinds.) Alright, alright.

speaker: JERRY
words: Is that it?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Stopped dead.

speaker: JERRY
words: What do you make of it?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I don't know. (George sits down at the table. Kramer enters.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry. Uh, can we talk?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Kinda busy here.

speaker: KRAMER
words: I'd like to talk to Jerry in private.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Why can't I stay?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Because it doesn't concern you.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, if it doesn't concern me, then I can stay. (Kramer grabs the back of George's chair, drags him out into the hallway and closes the door.)

speaker: JERRY
words: So, what's on your mind?

speaker: KRAMER
words: It's Pam.

speaker: JERRY
words: Pam? What about Pam?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I love her, Jerry!

speaker: JERRY
words: You what?

speaker: KRAMER
words: I love her!

speaker: JERRY
words: Is that right?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, she's uh...she's real. She can bring home the bacon and fry it in the pan.

speaker: JERRY
words: What does that mean?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, and that voice!

speaker: JERRY
words: What about her name?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Pam? Oh, it's a beautiful name. (Kramer sits on the couch.) Pam. Pam. Pam!

speaker: JERRY
words: She's got really nice hair.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, it's incredible. Although, I might replace her tortoise clip with one of those velvet scrunchies. I love those.

speaker: JERRY
words: You've got really specific tastes.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, I know what I want, Jerry.

speaker: JERRY
words: She's got nice calves.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, she's a dreamboat. But, you don't like her, so...

speaker: JERRY
words: Maybe I could, you're making some pretty good points.

speaker: KRAMER
words: No you can't, Jerry.

speaker: JERRY
words: But I might.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, no you don't.

speaker: JERRY
words: Why not? The voice? The calves? The bacon?

speaker: KRAMER
words: What...?

speaker: JERRY
words: I think I can! I even like the name! Pam!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Huh?

speaker: JERRY
words: Pam!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Huh?

speaker: JERRY
words: Pam!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Huh-yah! (Kramer loses it and runs out past George, who is still sitting in the hallway on a chair.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: So now he wants her more than ever!

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Blast!

speaker: KRAMER
words: What am I gonna do, huh?

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Don't despair, my friend. (Newman walks in front of Kramer and trips over his feet. Again.) I won't allow your love to go unrequited. Not like mine.

speaker: KRAMER
words: What, again with you?

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Sorry. But love is spice with many tastes. A dizzying array of textures...and moments.

speaker: KRAMER
words: If only I could say things like that around her.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Yes...

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I hear three distinct sounds. A low rumple...followed by a metallic 'squink'...

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yes! Yes, I heard the 'squink'!

speaker: ELAINE
words: ...followed by a mysterious...'glonk.'

speaker: GEORGE
words: It's baffling, isn't it?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, one question does come to mind. Have you considered just...asking them what happened to the briefcase?

speaker: GEORGE
words: They would never tell me, Elaine. First of all, they probably think that I killed Susan. Besides, I don't even think they like me. (Jerry comes over to the table.)

speaker: JERRY
words: That Pam! I am ga-ga over her!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Ga-ga? When did that happen?

speaker: JERRY
words: Yesterday. Six-ish.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, maybe we should double. I'm pretty ga-ga myself.

speaker: JERRY
words: You just met the guy yesterday.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, but we have a common goal.

speaker: JERRY
words: A barren, sterile existence that ends when you die?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah.

speaker: GEORGE
words: And you really believe this guy doesn't want to have kids.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, of course.

speaker: JERRY
words: Elaine, a guy'll say anything to get a woman.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, please. He wouldn't say that.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Elaine, I once told a woman that I coined the phrase, "Pardon my French."

speaker: JERRY
words: I once told a woman that I don't eat cake 'cause it goes right to my thighs.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I once told a woman that I really enjoy spending time with my family.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: With your looks and my words, we'll have built the perfect beast. (Kramer claps him on the shoulder, then goes to the other side of the aisle to talk to Pam.)

speaker: PAM
words: Oh, hi! Kramer.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Hi. How are you?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Hi. How are you?

speaker: PAM
words: I'm great.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: I too am well.

speaker: KRAMER
words: I too am well.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Do I smell Pantene?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Do I smell?

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Pantene!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Uh, Pantene.

speaker: PAM
words: Oh, my shampoo. Yeah, it is Pantene, I got a free sample in with my junk mail.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, there really is no junk-mail...well, everybody wants to get a check or a birthday card, but...

speaker: NEWMAN
words: ...it takes just as much man-power to deliver it as their precious little greeting cards...

speaker: KRAMER
words: Newman! (Elbows him through the books. Newman falls over.)

speaker: PAM
words: What?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Uh, human. It's...human to be moved by a fragrance.

speaker: PAM
words: That's so true.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Her bouquet cleaved his hardened...

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Shell.

speaker: KRAMER
words: ...shell. And fondled his muscled heart. He embibed her glistening spell...just before the other shoe...fell.

speaker: PAM
words: Kramer, that is so lovely.

speaker: KRAMER
words: It's by an unknown 20th-century poet.

speaker: PAM
words: Oh, what's his name?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Newman. (On the other side of the bookcase, Newman preens proudly.)

speaker: KEVIN
words: Elaine, you've changed my life.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Oh, Kevin...you can go on and on about how you don't want kids...and it sounds, it sounds really nice, but...the truth is, I don't know if you mean it or not.

speaker: KEVIN
words: I got a vasectomy this morning.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Although, I have a hunch you mean it.

speaker: JERRY
words: I just came by to tell you - I'm really, really happy about this relationship. Really happy.

speaker: PAM
words: Oh. Well, that's um...(clears her throat)...nice. (Jerry looks suspicious. Pam turns around and Jerry notices her tortoise clip has been replaced with a velvet scrunchie.)

speaker: JERRY
words: Kramer!

speaker: JERRY
words: Hello, Newman.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Hello, Jerry. How's Pam?

speaker: JERRY
words: Pam? What do you care? (Newman shrugs. Jerry notices he's carrying a Brentano's bookstore bag.)

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Well, ta-ta! (Scampers away.)

speaker: JERRY
words: Wait a minute! (A manic chase scene ensues, with Jerry chasing Newman from one end of the building to the other. Jerry finally catches up with him in the hallway on another floor.)

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright, Newman! This is it! (Shoves him against the wall.)

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Easy, Jerry. Steady. You wouldn't want to lose your cool at a time like this.

speaker: JERRY
words: Why not?

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Because right now, I'm the only chance you've got. (Newman giggles nervously. Jerry makes Newman flinch, and his giggling is choked off.)

speaker: JERRY
words: C'mon. (They exit.)

speaker: JERRY
words: I can't believe I'm losing Pam!

speaker: NEWMAN
words: I know how you feel. For I, too, have a woman for whom I pine.

speaker: JERRY
words: I thought we were talking about me.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Right.

speaker: JERRY
words: Anyway, I don't need your help. (Turns to leave.)

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Oh, don't you? Joke boy? You really think you can manipulate that beautiful young woman like the half-soused nightclub rabble that lap up your inane "observations"?

speaker: JERRY
words: Alright, Newman. What do I have to do to get you to stop pulling the strings for Kramer?

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Well, there is a little something you can do for me...

speaker: JERRY
words: C'mon, out with it.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: It's about...Elaine.

speaker: JERRY
words: Elaine? What does she have to - (notices Newman looking up at him longlingly.) Oh no...

speaker: NEWMAN
words: You dated her. Give me some inside information. Anything I can use!

speaker: JERRY
words: Well, I know she doesn't want to have kids. (Newman considers the implications of this.)

speaker: KEVIN
words: I thought you'd be a little more enthusiastic about it.

speaker: ELAINE
words: I know, I don't want...(clears her throat)...kids.

speaker: KEVIN
words: What was that?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, Kevin, maybe I have a little doubt. I mean, nothing is a hundred percent.

speaker: KEVIN
words: This is! Oh boy, I always do this.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What?

speaker: KEVIN
words: Oh, I get all jazzed up about something and I go way to far with it.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Really?

speaker: KEVIN
words: Oh, yeah. Like last summer. I'm watchin' TV and I saw one of those jet-skis. $4000 later and it's sitting in my garage.

speaker: ELAINE
words: You know, that's weird, actually, 'cause I'm sort of the same way. I mean once for like, no reason, I flattened my hair and I had all these strands hanging in my face all the time...

speaker: KEVIN
words: Sometimes I think I do want kids. Maybe a lot of kids!

speaker: ELAINE
words: Sometimes I think about wearing my hair real short.

speaker: KEVIN
words: Yeah! I think I like short hair. Really short.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah!

speaker: KEVIN
words: Yeah!

speaker: GEORGE
words: This is a crude mock-up of the conference room. 114th scale.

speaker: JERRY
words: When did you build this thing?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yesterday, took the day off. (Picks up a red Power Ranger action figure from the model and pretends it's him.) Now, from the time I left the room...

speaker: JERRY
words: Wait, that's you?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Yeah.

speaker: JERRY
words: I really think the M&M should be you.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Alright, whatever! Now. Whatever caused the damage...(drops a tiny briefcase onto the table in the model)...was jarring enough to completely stop the tape.

speaker: JERRY
words: And?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Okay. That's what we know.

speaker: JERRY
words: But we already knew that.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Well, yeah.

speaker: JERRY
words: Just give me some idea of what you think it could be.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I don't know if you're ready for it.

speaker: JERRY
words: Please.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I believe that I am about to become the target of a systematic process of intimidation and manipulation, the likes of which you have never -

speaker: JERRY
words: Hold it, hold it! You're right, I'm not ready for this. (The door buzzer sounds, Jerry answers it.) Yeah?

speaker: VOICE ON SPEAKER
words: It's Pam.

speaker: JERRY
words: C'mon up. (To George) Alright, it's Pam, you gotta get goin.'

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'm not through here, Jerry. (Picks up the model of the conference room.) I'm gonna keep on investigating. This thing is like an onion. The more layers you peel, the more it stinks. (Pam enters, George leaves.)

speaker: PAM
words: What was that?

speaker: JERRY
words: We were just playin.'

speaker: PAM
words: Listen, I had a long talk with Kramer today...

speaker: JERRY
words: Uh huh...

speaker: PAM
words: Well, the thing is, I uh...I think I have a little crush on him. (Kramer slides in the door on his knees.)

speaker: KRAMER
words: I'm so happy! My world suddenly has meaning!

speaker: JERRY
words: This is the man you have a crush on?

speaker: PAM
words: Well, I have feelings for both of you.

speaker: KRAMER
words: How can you have feelings for him? We're soul mates.

speaker: JERRY
words: Why can't I be a soul mate?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Jerry, you really think that Pam would want you to be the father of her children?

speaker: PAM
words: Children? Who said anything about children? I don't want to have children.

speaker: GEORGE
words: There are some people in this room who would have been very happy to never see this briefcase again. There are people in this room who think they can destroy other people's property and get away with it. Well, let me tell you something about those people. They weren't counting on this brain! And this tape recorder.

speaker: WYCK
words: George...

speaker: GEORGE
words: You'll have your turn! The truth must be heard. (Plays back the tape.) That's all there was. And yet, it speaks volumes. A low rumple. A metallic 'squink.' A 'glonk.' Someone crying out..."Dear God!" Let's start with, uh...with you, Wyck.

speaker: WYCK
words: George, Quinn here was moving a chair...he lost his balance and dropped it...it must have fallen on your briefcase, which, for some reason, contained a running tape recorder?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Alright, then. We've gotten to the bottom of that.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What are you guys doing here?

speaker: JERRY
words: We're getting vasectomies.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Why?

speaker: NEWMAN
words: I'm doing it for you.

speaker: ELAINE
words: What?

speaker: JERRY
words: What'd you do to your hair?

speaker: ELAINE
words: I cut it.

speaker: JERRY
words: It's a little short.

speaker: KEVIN
words: Y'think?

speaker: JERRY
words: What are you doing here?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Kevin's having his vasectomy reversed.

speaker: JERRY AND NEWMAN
words: Reversed?! (Kramer comes hobbling out of the doctors office in pain, after having a vasectomy of his own, and exits. Jerry and Newman look at each other, and bolt for the door themselves.)

speaker: GEORGE
words: ...he embibed her glistening spell...just before the other shoe...fell.

speaker: WYCK
words: Is that a Keats poem?

speaker: GEORGE
words: No, it's a Newman. Well, I gotta run. (Smiles, pats his briefcase and exits.)

speaker: WYCK
words: Does anyone think George might have murdered Susan?

speaker: MR. CROSS
words: Oh, yeah. I just assumed he murdered her.

speaker: MS. BAINES
words: Of course he killed her.

speaker: WYCK
words: So it's not just me, then. Alright! Back to business.

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: All right. How 'bout this one: let's say you're abducted by aliens.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Fine.

speaker: JERRY
words: They haul you aboard the mother ship, take you back to their planet as a curiosity. Now: would you rather be in their zoo, or their circus?

speaker: GEORGE
words: I gotta go zoo. I feel like I could set more of my own schedule.

speaker: JERRY
words: But in the circus you get to ride around in the train, see the whole planet!

speaker: GEORGE
words: I'm wearin' a little hat, I'm jumpin' through fire.. They're puttin' their little alien heads in my mouth..

speaker: JERRY
words: (resigned) At least it's show business..

speaker: GEORGE
words: But in the zoo, you know, they might, put a woman in there with me to uh.. you know, get me to mate.

speaker: JERRY
words: What if she's got no interest in you?

speaker: GEORGE
words: W--then I'm pretty much where I am now. At least I got to take a ride on a spaceship.

speaker: KRAMER
words: George, why couldn't I use the bathroom in that store?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Krama, trust me, this is the best bathroom in midtown!

speaker: KRAMER
words: (frustrated) Wha??

speaker: JERRY
words: (dry) He knows.

speaker: GEORGE
words: {Anyway,} on the left--exquisite marble! High ceilings. An' a flush, like a jet engine! (imitates sound) Ha ha!

speaker: KRAMER
words: (impressed) Now, listen, uh. You better not wait. I'll catch you later.

speaker: GEORGE
words: You sure?

speaker: JERRY
words: (dry) He knows.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Wow.

speaker: JERRY
words: Why don't you try your engagement story?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (considers, but got into elevator) Won't work.

speaker: JERRY
words: Are you sure?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (wry) He knows.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Look. Kevin. I really like you, heh, heh, uh. But, um, maybe we'd be, better off just being.. friends. (takes a bite of her

speaker: KEVIN
words: Friends?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well. I mean. (distracted by the food) Oh, god. This tuna tastes like an old sponge.

speaker: KEVIN
words: Friends. Yeah! Why not friends? I might like to try that! Like you an' Jerry!

speaker: MAN
words: (frustrated) Damn thing is jammed again..

speaker: KRAMER
words: You know what happens with these? The rollers, they get flat spots on 'em. (hits button several times and whacks it)

speaker: MAN
words: Come on, let's go.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (absently wants to be part of it) Oh, yeah--yeah.. (follows them)

speaker: ELAINE
words: (to JERRY) Remember I was telling you about Gillian, my friend who writes for the L.L. Bean catalogue? I really think you

speaker: JERRY
words: (doubtful) I don't know, do you have a--

speaker: JERRY
words: Not bad. Wuh--what does she--

speaker: ELAINE
words: (dry) I put her stats on the back.

speaker: JERRY
words: Pretty impressive--"Serious boyfriend '92 to '95." Owns her own car.. "Favorite president: James Polk!" (ELAINE had

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hnn! Let me see that.

speaker: JERRY
words: (hands it to him as he asks ELAINE) So how'd it go with Kevin? Did you, steel-toe his ass back to Kentucky?

speaker: ELAINE
words: (laughs in appreciation) You are not gonna believe this! I told him that I just wanted to be friends. He's fine with it. He really

speaker: JERRY
words: Why would anybody want a friend.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (dread) Uh.

speaker: JERRY
words: I mean all that stuff is so small..

speaker: GEORGE
words: (still looking at that picture) You know if I told my engagement story to that receptionist, but told her this, was my fiance..

speaker: JERRY
words: What?

speaker: GEORGE
words: Don't you see. Women like that are like, members of a secret tribe living in a forbidden city. People like me have not been

speaker: ELAINE
words: (wry, not impressed) Well you cracked it! I warned the Queen you were gettin' close an', now it looks like we're gonna have to

speaker: GEORGE

speaker: JERRY
words: (Looks around his apartment) Is it better than mine?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Definite) Oh yeah.

speaker: JERRY
words: So, it's a two-bedroom-one-bath-make-your-friends-hate-ya?

speaker: GEORGE
words: You know what? It's better than Elaine's, too. I gotta give her a call. (Moves tward the phone)

speaker: JERRY
words: She's out.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Stops) Oh right, the blind date.

speaker: JERRY
words: Yeah, well, they like to call it a set-up now. I guess the blind people don't like being associated with all those losers.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Come on. Come check out my new place. It'll take you two minutes.

speaker: JERRY
words: I can't. I'm meeting Kramer down at my mini-storage.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Gloating) Hey, you got any extra furniture down there? I need some more stuff to fill that extra bedroom with the walk-in closet. (Smiles)

speaker: JERRY
words: (Grabs his coat) Oh, this is really annoying.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Laughs as they leave) It's working already! (Both exit)

speaker: JERRY
words: (Disgusted) What is with that?!

speaker: KRAMER
words: Well, it's coughing, Jerry. It expells the diseased germs out of the body, into the air. (Makes a guesture of germs being in the air)

speaker: JERRY
words: (Takes out his key to unlock the unit door) Where is your key?

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, well, uh, Newman. He's - he's got it.

speaker: JERRY
words: You know, Kramer, I rented out half of my space to you.

speaker: KRAMER
words: Yeah, and I rented out half that space to Newman. (Starts coughing again)

speaker: JERRY
words: (Picks one up) Mail bags? He's storing mail in here?

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Looks at the bags on the floor) Evidently.

speaker: RICARDI
words: Excuse me, George?

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Looks at her) Yeah, uh, no menus. (Waves her off)

speaker: RICARDI
words: (Moves into the apartment, hand out) No, I'm Mrs. Ricardi - president of the tenant's association.

speaker: GEORGE
words: Oh, right! (Shakes her hand) Right! Hey, hey.. I love the floors in here. It's like a gymnasium in here! Try and guard me! (Dribbles an imaginary ball) toward Mrs. Ricadi. She backs off defensively) Come on! (Stops and laughs right before running into her)

speaker: RICARDI
words: No, no.. (Laughs nervously) Uh, George, unfortunately, Clarance Eldridge in 8C has decided that he wants the apartment.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Let down) Yeah, but you - you promised it to me.

speaker: RICARDI
words: Yes, but, you see - Mister Eldridge is an Andrea Doria survivor. And, in light of the terrible suffering that he's already been through, we've decided to give it to him.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Depressed) Well,.. the Andrea Doria.. that was quite a fire. (Moves to the door, leaving).

speaker: RICARDI
words: (Correcting) Shipwreck.

speaker: GEORGE
words: I remember.. (Leaves)

speaker: ELAINE
words: Where is this guy?! (Checks her watch) I hate this! (Sighs) I shoulda brought something to read.. (Picks up a sugar packet) "Cancer in labratory animals"..

speaker: WAITER

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah?

speaker: WAITER
words: An Alan Mercer called for you. He said he's sorry, but he won't be able to make it tonight. (Pause) He's been stabbed.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Shocked) Stabbed?!

words: More bread?

words: (Talking to Elaine) You ate more bread?

words: That is not the point! The guy was stabbed!

words: Did you find out who stabbed him?

speaker: ELAINE
words: Yeah, (Nodding) It turns out it was his ex-girlfriend.

speaker: JERRY
words: (Like a father) Well, you're not going near this hooligan anymore.

speaker: ELAINE
words: Well, I don't know.. I mean, think about it, Jerry. There must be something exciting about this guy if he can arouse that kind of passion. (Obviously turned

words: (Sarcastic) Yeah, too bad he didn't get shot. He could have been the one.

words: (Coughs) Hey. How's everybody? (Moves to the kitchen)

words: Hey.

words: Ehh.. (Picks up a carton of food) No expiration date on this.. (Opens it, then starts coughing directly onto the food)

words: There is now. Kramer, you should really get that cough checked out by a doctor.

speaker: KRAMER
words: (Shrugging it off) Nah, no, no, no. No doctors for me. A bunch of lackeys and yes-men all towing the company line.. (Looks at Jerry, then leans in so

words: (In awe. Whispering) The botched it?

words: (Complaining) I'm even more potent now!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Hey.

words: Hey. How's the new place?!

speaker: GEORGE
words: Gone. (Moves over to a chair in the living room. Kramer takes the carton of food to the table, and begins eating) The tenant association made me give it

words: (Talking about his would-be apartment) You could fit 15 people in that bathroom..

words: I think Gordon Lightfoot was the boat.

words: (Sarcastic) Yeah, and it was rammed by the Cat Stevens.

words: (Like a teacher) The Andrea Doria collided with the Stockholm in dense fog 21 miles off the coast of Nantucket. (Makes a clicking sound with his

words: That's it?! I thought it was, like, a thousand!

words: There were 1,650 survivors.

words: That's no tragedy! How many people do you lose on a normal cruse? 30? 40?! Kramer, can I take a look at that book? (Starts walking tward the door.

words: Oh yeah. I also got "Astounding Bear Attacks"

words: Yeah, oh, yeah. Yeah, he's not gonna do it. (Leaves)

words: To Hawaii. The most sought-after postal route of them all. The air is so dewy-sweet you don't even have to like the stamps.. But it's not to be - So, I'm

words: Kind of. I'm still collecting checks, I'm just not delivering mail.

words: Well, get it out of my storage. It's illegal.

words: Carol?

words: (Fast) Well, you know when you break up, how you say things you don't mean? Well, he says the mean things you don't mean, but he means them.

words: (Nods) I follow. So what are you gonna do?

words: Dump him. I can't be with someone who doesn't break up nicely. I mean, to me, that's one of the most important parts of a relationship.

words: (Agreeing) What's more important?

words: Oh..

speaker: KRAMER
words: Oh, I'll take a vet over an M.D. any day. They gotta be able to cure a (Snaps his fingers in rhythm with his words) lizard, a chicken, a pig, a frog (Stops

words: Well, all vacations have to end eventually.

words: The boat sank.

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Holding up Kramer's book) According to this, it took.. 10 hours. It eased into the water like an old man into a nice warm bath - no offence. (Pause) So,

words: (Yelling out) It's my apartment, Eldridge! The Stalkholm may not have sunk ya, but I will! Ha, ha, ha!

words: Well, uh.. it hurts when he swallows. Expecially when he drinks orange juice. (Vet gives him a look) I mean, uh.. dog food.. juice. (Adding) What's

words: (Offended) What? No. That's disgusting..

words: So that's it? We're, uh, we're breakin' up?

words: (Fast) Ok, yeah, sure, fine, right. Whatever you say.

speaker: ALAN
words: You got a big head. It's too big for your body. (Walks for the door)

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Laughing out loud) That's it?! (Laughs again) That's the best you got?! (Laughs loudly as Alan exits)

speaker: GEORGE
words: So, he's keeping the apartment. He doesn't deserve it, though! Even if he did suffer, that was, like, 40 years ago! What has he been doing lately?! I've

words: Jerry!

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Blast! There's no way I can handle 8 in addition to my ususal load of one! I'll never get to Hawaii! (Moves over to Jerry's couch, depressed) I'll be

speaker: NEWMAN

speaker: JERRY

speaker: JERRY
words: (Like an Army general) Elaine, Newman is my sworn enemy. And he lives down the hall from my home - my home, Elaine! Where I sleep, where I come to

words: (Gestures to his throat) No, my throat's too tender.

words: I don't want to!

words: Lean your head back. Open your mouth! (Grabs Kramer's head) Open your mouth! Open it! Open it!

words: (Reads the pill bottle) What kind of pills are these, anyways?! "For Smuckers"? "May cause panting and loss of fur"? (Turns to Kramer) These are dog

words: I don't know..

words: Get outta here! We have a booth.

words: Order a hot dish.

words: Why can't we sit over there? (Points to a table)

words: (Yelling) That's not a booth!

words: (Trying to match Frank's loudness) So, who says we have to sit in a booth?!

speaker: FRANK
words: (Loud shouting) I didn't take the subway all the way to New York to sit at a table like that! (Gestures to the table)

words: (Nagging yell) Well, I didn't take the subway to be in a drafty restaurant!

speaker: GEORGE
words: (Pleading for them to stop) Mom.. dad.

words: Now, George, what do you want to know about your childhood?

words: (Fed up with his parents) Actually, I think I'm pretty clear on it.

words: (Looks up) Where's that breeze coming from?

words: No, Jerry!

words: No! Don't!

words: Hey, hey! Get back over here! Kramer! Get over here! You are bad! Bad neighbor! Kramer!

words: Bit you?!

words: We had an arguement about me going to Hawaii, and he locked onto my ankle like it was a soup bone. I'm hubbled! I don't think I can do my route -

words: I could give you my uniform from my rookie year.

speaker: JERRY

words: (Hands him some mail) There you go. Merry Chirstmas!

speaker: NEWMAN
words: "Do not bend". (Laughs evilly) Just crease, crumple, cram.. you'll do fine. (Phone rings. Newman answers it) Hello?.. This is he. I don't understand..

words: What?

words: That was the Vice President of the post office. I didn't get the transfer.. They knew it wasn't me doing my route!

words: (Pleading) I tried my best!

speaker: NEWMAN
words: Exactly. You're a disgrace to the uniform. (Newman takes off Jerry's mailman hat. Jerry turns his head in shame. Newman then tears the post office

words: You know, this is your coat.

speaker: NEWMAN
words: (Realizing) Damn!

words: (Rubbing her head to relieve the pain) Really?

words: They're making their decision today.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Annoyed, near tears) The one that sits atop my disproportunately puny body.. I'm a walking candy apple!

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Realizing) What? Yeah.. you're right!.. All I have to do is call him up, and sit with him, and show him that it doesn't bother me. You know, laugh it off.. or

words: (Casually, sarcastic) Either way.

speaker: ELAINE
words: (Getting up to leave) Alright.

speaker: ALAN
words: I want to apologize for..

words: (Shrugging it off) Oh, please.

speaker: THE END
words: THE END

speaker: JERRY
words: So what happened to you yesterday? We were supposed to go to the auto show, I waited for you, you never came.

words: I'm sorry, I got really busy. How long did you wait?

words: Five minutes.

words: What's the difference? You never showed up.

words: Well, we barely knew the guy.

speaker: ELAINE
words: So, the longer you know someone, the shorter you wait for 'em.

speaker: JERRY
words: That's the way it works.
